loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en: For the last two years, Ricardo D. of Sto. Niño has made a living raising hogs. He is married and has five children, and he and his wife work hard to support their family. Together, they earn about 3,000 PHP a month. Ricardo also tills a small parcel of land where he plants and harvests rice. He would like to expand his businesses but is hampered by a lack of funds. He recently learned about our lending program, and is applying for his first loan to buy items he needs for his farm, such as additional livestock and feed, medicine and vitamins for his hogs. He hopes this loan will allow him to increase his income, better care for his family and expand his small livestock and farming businesses.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his farming and livestock businesses

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia makes a living by running a farm on the outskirts of Kitale town in Western Kenya. She has been farming for 20 years and now employs two people. Her farm produces maize, beans, vegetables, tea and milk, all of which she sells at a local market.

Julia is 49 years old, married and blessed with four children who range in age from 22 and 30. One of her children is still in school.

Julia has a good record with Juhudi Kilimo, having successfully repaid previous four loans. She is applying for a new loan, for 50,000 KES, to expand her poultry business. She hopes that this will allow her to increase her family's standard of living and reduce the threat of poultry diseases.

In the future, she hopes to expand her livestock business and begin raising more exotic types of poultry.

loans.use: To expand her farm

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley O. lives the village of Purok de Oro, Iligan City. She is 46 years old, married and has four school-aged children. She makes a living by selling snacks and delicacies popular in her community. She has been in this business for more than two years, and earns about 5,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Shirley joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for a loan, her first, for 5,000 PHP to buy the ingredients she needs to make the items she sells. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy the ingredients she needs to make items to sell to her customers

location.town: Purok de Oro, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn P. hails from Sto. Niño. She is 45 years old and is married with children aged 22 and 15.

Together with her husband, Evelyn has been farming rice for more than a few years now to provide for her family’s needs. She wants to increase her income for her family’s benefit and so she applied for a loan.

The loan will be used for the expenses of tilling the land in preparation for the planting season and to buy seedlings and fertilizer. Any additional income will go to support her family’s daily consumption and to her child’s education.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Puma Group

texts.en:
Lameck A., who is in his mid-forties, is a divorcee, and has three children, aged 17, 13 and 9. In the photo, he is the only man.

Lameck currently runs a fruit and vegetable stall, as well as selling baskets. He has been doing this for almost twenty years, and works daily between 8 a.m. and 7 p.m. He currently makes a fair monthly profit.

This will be Lameck’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. With this loan, he aims to increase his stock of baskets. His dream is to earn enough money to build his own house, and he strongly believes that increasing his stock of baskets will help achieve this dream.

Lameck will share this loan with his loan group, Puma, which totals sixteen members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To make and sell more baskets.

loans.name: Priseah

texts.en:
Priseah has been practicing mixed farming for the last eight years in Kitale town, Western Kenya. Her mixed farm produces tea, milk, maize, beans and vegetables which she sells at a local market. She also owns and operates a shop in the same location. 

Priseah is 31 years old. She is married with three children who are between the ages of 2 and 13. Two of the children attend school.

She has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 85,000KES to start a poultry project and build a dairy unit. She says that with this loan, her sources of income will increase and she will be able to have enough money to cover the basic needs of her family.

Priseah hopes that in five years' time, her business will generate enough income to enable her expand and upgrade her farming. Her primary challenge has been the fluctuation in market prices. She hopes that Juhudi will continue to fund her.

loans.use: To start a poultry project and build a dairy shed

loans.name: Nafuu

texts.en:
Nafuu is a married woman with one child who is still young for school. She has been operating her business of selling kikois (large colorful fabrics) (Leso) for the last two years, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She has no other source of income.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase a bale of kikois for resale. Nafuu faces the major challenge of high transportation costs in her business, as she moves from door to door. She hopes to succeed in business and become self reliant.

She owns a house with electricity but no running water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of kikois for resale

loans.name: Dashdavaa

texts.en:
Dashdavaa H. is 54 years old and lives with his wife in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his wife live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All his children are married and live separately from their parents.

Dashdavaa operates a grocery business in his town. He started his business in 2000 with the help of his wife and has steadily grown his business over the years. He purchases all his vegetables from wholesale stores at a cheap price. He owns a cellar that can hold up to 10 tons of vegetables. His wife, Tsendsuren, usually sells a variety of vegetables in a local market as well. In addition, Dashdavaa runs a taxi service in the morning and evening to supplement his earnings.

Dashdavaa is a very optimistic and hardworking person who has more than ten years of business experience. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory such as soup, washing powder, toilet paper and other products at wholesale prices for his grocery business. He hopes to have his own workplace in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth N., 52 years old, lives in Magongo, Mombasa. She is married to Mwandoe N. who also works and adds to the family income. They are blessed with two children.

Elizabeth has been a greengrocer for the last ten years, and she says that business has been good so far. She supplements her income by selling secondhand clothes to friends and family members.

This is Elizabeth’s third loan from KADET; she repaid her previous loans well and on time. She would like to purchase more groceries for her store and additional secondhand clothes to sell. She hopes to use the anticipated profit to expand her business.

Elizabeth hopes to be a prosperous business lady and take her children to good schools.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and secondhand clothes to sell

loans.name: Abubakar

texts.en:
Abubakar D. is a 36-year-old landlord and carpenter with a carpentry shop in Miritini, Mombasa. He is married to Mwajumbe, and they have two children. Abubakar has been in the carpentry business for the last two years, and he has been successful. His monthly income is enough to sustain him and his family’s needs.

This will be Abubakar’s second loan from KADET. He would like to add to his stock of timber in his carpentry shop and use the anticipated profit to boost his wife’s business.

In the future Abubakar would like to open up a bigger hardware shop in Mombasa.

loans.use: To add to his stock of timber

loans.name: Kimdy

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimdy S., 50, has been selling vegetables for almost 20 years. She has six children -- four sons and two daughters. Three of them are garment factory workers and the other three are in school. The family lives in a small village about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Kimdy wants to expand her business by buying dried and smoked fish to sell, but she does not have capital. So she is applying for her first loan of $600. She will also use part of her loan to expand her house where she raises cows.

loans.use: To purchase dried and smoked fish to sell.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John S. is a 64-year-old married father of two children. He is a carpenter in Shanzu and has operated the carpenty shop for over 30 years. This has been his family's main source of income.

This is John's second loan from KADET and he plans to buy timber stock for his business. He mainly serves the residents of Shanzu, Mombasa and its environs. He hopes to use the anticipated profit to pay for his children's education.

He hopes to own a school in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase timber.

loans.name: Davaahuu

texts.en: Davaahuu T. is a 48-year-old widow and lives with her grown daughter in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. She and her daughter live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  Davaahuu operates a dairy trading business in her town.  She started this business in 2006 with working capital of 45,000 MNT which has since grown to 1,800,000 MNT. Over the years of running her business, Davaahuu has gained a reputation among her customers as a reliable supplier of quality dairy products. She has also been able to gain a lot of business knowledge and experience during this time. Her business earnings have enabled her to purchase a new car for her son. She is a very honest and hardworking businesswoman and is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to prepare more dairy products in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: To prepare more dairy products

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en:
Emmy has a mixed farm in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya. She has been farming for 10 years. Her main products are cabbages, beans, potatoes, milk and tea which she sells at a local market. She also earns income from her kiosk in the same area.

Emmy is 37 years old. She is married with 5 children who are now between the ages of 4 and 14. Four of the children attend school.

Emmy has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 70,000KES to purchase a dairy cow. With this loan she will be able to acquire a quality cow that will increase her milk production. She will therefore be able to provide enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. She however faces the challenge of insufficient dairy feed.

In the future, she plans to improve her farming by keeping the best dairy breeds and planting more grass and other dairy feed for her animals. She is grateful for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sam-An

texts.en:
Mr. Sam-an M. and his wife, Mrs. Samphor Heng (pictured together), have been married since 1986 and have four children -- two sons and two daughters. One of the daughters is married and lives outside the family home.  The other three children are in school. The family lives in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sam-an is a deputy school principal of a college. His wife sells meal in a school near their house. Sam-an now is applying for his second loan of $600 to pay school fees for his son to continue his studies in his third year.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his son to continue his studies in his third year.

loans.name: Salome Kagwira

texts.en:
Salome K. is 31 years old and married to Dominic K., a businessman. They have one child. Salome has been operating a beauty salon for about two years now, and she is able to make approximately 28,000 KES a month.

With her first loan from KADET, Salome intends to buy a new hair dryer. With the anticipated profit, she wants to stock the salon with more cosmetics and beauty products. She would like to open a cosmetics shop that can supply products to other small-scale shops in Thika.

loans.use: To buy a hair dryer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Nassiri

texts.en:
Nassiri J., 38, is married to Hamida Lyunus, and he supports their entire family by himself. He lives in Chaani Magongo, Mombasa. He has owned and run a restaurant for eight years, and he makes a good enough income to cater to his and his family’s needs.

This will be Nassiri’s first loan from KADET. He plans to purchase food inventories for his restaurant and use the anticipated profit to boost the business. In the future J. hopes to open a spare auto parts shop.

loans.use: To purchase food inventories for his restaurant

loans.name: Delger

texts.en:
Delger L. is 30 years old, a married man living with his wife and three grown-up children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his family have been living together in their current home for the past 17 years. His older son, 23, and daughter, 19, are both university students while his middle son, 21, currently serves in the Mongolian military. 

Delger operates a vegetable trading business in his town with the help of his wife. He provides a large selection of vegetables to his customers. He started his grocery business in 2006, and since then he has been able to increase his working capital. During several years of successful business activity, he has used his earnings to provide for his family and was able to cover his children's educational expenditures. 

For the future, he is planning to build a new cellar for preserving vegetables out of his earnings. Moreover, he hopes for continued success and to purchase more vegetables and says, " I continue to provide for my children's education. From my future expected earnings, I will build a new cellar in my yard." He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of vegetables and preserve them for the coming autumn months when prices for those products traditionally decrease.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of vegetables

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda C. is from the village of Faustino, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Luzviminda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzviminda has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Luzviminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is a farmer from the town of Nyamira in western Kenya. She has been practising mixed farming for the last twelve years. Her farm produces milk, tea, maize and beans which she sells at a local market. Norah is 37 years old. She is married with 5 school-aged children.

Norah has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of  45,000KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable her to pay school fees for her children and increase her stock of maize and beans.

In future, she hopes to buy more agricultural land and acquire two  more dairy cows. She faces the challenge of animal diseases.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Phin

texts.en:
Mr. Phin B. (pictured here) and his wife, Mrs. Sophy Leav, live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1987 and have three children--two sons and one daughter. Two of their children have full-time employment in Phnom Penh, and another one attends school.

Phin is a motor taxi driver. He is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a sugar cane juice machine for his wife. In the past, Mrs. Sophy Leav used to be a silk weaver, but she quit that business.

loans.use: To purchase a sugar cane juice machine for his wife's business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary has been managing her mixed farm for ten years in Nyamira town, western Kenya. Her farm produces milk, tea, bananas and maize which she sells locally. She is a happy farmer since she has been able to cater for the basic needs of her family with the income from her farm.

Mary is 41 years old. She is married with 6 children who are between the ages of 13 and 22. Four of the children attend  school.

Mary has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo in the amount of 45,000KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable her to pay school fees for her children and improve the livelihood of her family. She hopes to acquire 5 dairy cows and 5 acres of land in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is from the village of Faustino, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 41 years old. Elizabeth is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Elizabeth is just starting this business.

In 2010, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Elizabeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Delgersaihan

texts.en:
Delgersaihan M. is 41 years old, a married man who lives with his wife and four children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. His oldest two daughters both attend university while his son attends a local secondary school. He and his family live together in a "ger", a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife has been operating a milk-selling business to support her family for the last 5 years.

 Delgersaihan used to work as a guard for a company and in 2009, he started selling the coal and firewood in his town. Both family businesses depend on the season, which means that during winter months, his coal and firewood-selling business becomes very profitable because of increasing demand for his products for use in heating, while his wife's milk-selling business is very active in the summer months. 

Delgersaihan  is a very optimistic and laborious businessman. He has used his earnings to cover his two daughters' educational costs. Delgersaihan is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more coal and dried droppings of cattle  to resell as fuel.

loans.use: To purchase more coal and dried droppings of cattle

loans.name: Kyeva

texts.en:
Kyeva I. is a 49-year-old herbal products trader in town center, Mombasa.  Kyeva is married to one wife who is also a businesswoman who also contributes to the family income. They are blessed with two children.

Kyeva has been in this business for the last three years and his income is great. He is now requesting his first loan with KADET and he would like to add to his inventory of "Forever Living" herbal medicinal products with the loan amount. He plans to use the anticipated profit to expand this business even more.

Kyeva hopes to be successful and become a leading supplier and a distributor of Forever Living products

loans.use: To purchase more Forever Living herbal medicinal products

loans.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mr. Yat S. and his wife, Mrs. Sarum Ket, have been married since 1979 and have six children--four sons and two daughters. Two of their sons are married and live outside the family home and the other two are construction workers. Both daughter are garment factory workers.

Yat is a fisherman. His wife sells the fish that her husband catches. He is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 300 to purchase fishing nets for his fishing business. 

In the past, Mrs. Sarum Ket used to be a silk weaver, but she quit the business.

Photo: Yat’s wife.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets for his fishing business

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida D. is from the village of Lactawan Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 59 years old. Leonida is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Leonida owns & operates a motorcycle transport business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport to local community members. Leonida has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Leonida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used for the repair and maintenance of the vehicle used in the business. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Leonida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: for the repair and maintenance of the vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel M. is a 34-year old farmer and supplier of building materials in the Shanzu area. He is married and they are blessed with one child. His wife supports him in his work in the farm. Daniel has been in this business for the past four years he says that his monthly income is enough to support his family needs.

This marks Daniel’s second loan from KADET. With this loan, he would like to purchase dairy cows. He will use the anticipated profit to educate his child and also to improve his business. In the future. Daniel would like to be successful in life: become a leading supplier of building materials and to be a prosperous farmer.

loans.use: To purchase dairy cows.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 27-year old single man from Lebanon. He is the main income provider for his family and he helps his father with the large expenses. He has seven years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own poultry farm since 2008. He works independently in his business. His work consists in delivering the chickens to some poultry shops in his town. Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase needed supplies for his farm such as fodders. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profits by 15%. 

And in the future, he is planning to rent a bigger land and build a large poultry farm.

loans.use: to purchase needed supplies for his farm such as fodders

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoeun H. (was in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Chhunnat Khim, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1994 and have four children -- two sons and two daughters. Three of them are in school and another one stays home. 

Savoeun has been a silk weaver since 1992. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell at Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been a mason for more than fourteen years.

Savoeun is requesting a loan of $800 to build a restroom for family use, and to buy a bicycle for her children to drive to school and to use for her weaving business.

loans.use: To build a restroom for family use, and to buy a bicycle for her children to drive to school and to use for her weaving business.

loans.name: Norm

texts.en:
Norm N., 38, is married and resides with his wife and six children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. (Note: N.'s wife appears in the photograph because N. is not available.)

N. is a security guard for a private company with an income of $5.00 U.S. dollars per day. His wife grows vegetables at home, earning an income of $1.50 U.S. dollars per day.  

N. is requesting a loan of $1,100 U.S. dollars to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to commute to work.

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en:
Nieves M. is from the village of Faustino, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Nieves is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Nieves raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Nieves has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,800 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nieves joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nieves is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nieves from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Gantumur

texts.en:
Gantumur O. is a 29-year old single woman who lives with her mother in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her mother live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

Gantumur operates a clothing retail business at the local market. She started her own private business in 2005 by selling a variety of fruits. In 2009, she began to operate a clothing trading business and has since built a stable operation. She has found success in her trade and has used her earnings to purchase a new truck. She hired her brother as a truck driver and pays him a monthly salary from her earnings. 

In the future, Gantumur hopes to continue her success and to build her own new house from her revenue. Her working capital has decreased because of purchasing the new truck, therefore, she is requesting a 2,000,000 Mongolian Tugrik (MNT) loan to purchase more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mr. Sim P.  (in the photo), 53, and his wife, Mrs. Nai Srey, 51, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They married in 1980 and have three children--one son and two daughters. All of them are married; two live separately and one lives in the family home.  

Sim and his wife sell fish and vegetables. In addition, they also grow mushrooms at home. Sim is applying for a loan of US$ 1,200 to expand his business by purchasing more fish and vegetables for resale. He will use part of the loan for growing mushrooms as well.

loans.use: To purchase fish and vegetables for resale and use for growing mushrooms

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with nine children; two  have completed school while the others still attend school. She has been operating her restaurant for over ten years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she does weaving, contributing another source of income.

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. Her major challenge in the business is seasonality especially during the months of August few customers turn up.

She hopes that someday she will be able to be self-reliant to satisfy her family's basic needs. She decided to join Yehu so as to get a loan to boost her family's income. She lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar

loans.name: Rean

texts.en: Rean V., 35, is married and resides with his wife and four children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. V. and his wife sell groceries at home for a gross income of USD 20 per day.  V. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Lung

texts.en:
Lung S., 42, is married and resides with her husband and nine children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. She provides laundry services for an income of USD 3.50 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 2.50 per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to pay one of the children's university fees.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: pay her child's university fees

loans.name: Munhbayar

texts.en:
Munhbayar B. is 29 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in a "ger", a traditional Mongolian nomadic dwelling, in Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. The couple has been blessed with two sons; one is currently attending a local kindergarten and other is an infant. His wife stays at home and takes care of her younger son. 

Using his own truck, Munhbayar operates a coal trading business in his town. Munhbayar started his business in 2008, and since then, he has made enough money to buy a new trailer that costs 1,500,000 MNT for his truck in August, 2010. His new trailer has enabled him to reduce his trip costs and to increase his revenue. 

Munhbayar is a well-esteemed and hardworking person and says, “I hope to increase my business profits so that I will be able to build my own house with a fenced yard for my family.” He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of coal for his working capital as well as to change his truck tires.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of coal

loans.name: Katana

texts.en:
Katana is a married man with seven children (three boys and four girls) who all attend school. He has been operating a food stall for the last year. He sells food from a shop and from home to neighbors, students and passers-by. His wife helps in the running of the food stall.
Previously, Katana was employed as a shop assistant. With his loan of 20,000 KES, he wants to add stock by purchasing a sack of beans, rice, cooking oil and charcoal for cooking. Katana faces the major challenges of competition and seasonality in his business. During June his business does very well because of schoolchildren but business decreases during August because most students are on holiday.
Katana hopes to open a business selling firewood in the future in order to make more profit to enable him to provide for his family's needs. He joined Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to improve his living standards and also his business. Katana rents a house with no electricity or piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing, school fees and rent bills.

loans.use: To purchase a sack of beans, rice, cooking oil and charcoal for cooking

loans.name: Mwanaharusi

texts.en:
Mwanaharusi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a taxi driver and he contributes to meet the family's needs.
Mwanaharusi has been operating a tailoring business for the last year. She works from home and sews for schoolchildren and neighbors. Her major business challenge is seasonality. With her loan of 40,000 KES, she wants to purchase a bundle of materials. She hopes to be self-reliant so that she is able to live a better life in the future.
Mwanaharusi decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to get a loan to boost her business. She lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Her biggest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of materials

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna P. is from the village of Bonfal Proper, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Myrna is married and has 6 children. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a vending business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting  a variety of fruits and vegetables for sale. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Myrna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sagynbiubiu's Group

texts.en:
Sagynbiubiu D. is the leader of this group. She is forty-three and married. Her husband is an officer. Sagynbiubiu is a constructor. She wants to purchase chickens and start selling eggs. She has all necessary conditions at home for chicken farming but she doesn’t have sufficient funds to purchase chickens. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase chickens.  One of her latest achievements is construction of her house. In the future, she wants to expand her business. 

Group members:

Rahat S. K. is treasurer of the group. She is twenty-seven and married. She has a child and her child goes to kindergarten. Her husband is serviceman. She has her pavilion where she sells convenience goods. She started selling convenience goods three years ago with an initial investment of 15,000 soms. Now, she has been able to increase her profits to 18,000 soms.  She is applying for a loan in order to purchase goods to increase her turnover and purchase a cupboard for her pavilion. In the future, she is planning to save some money for the purchase of a car for her husband. 

Nurlan K. is thirty-eight and married. He has two children. His son goes to school and his daughter is at home. His wife is a seamstress. Nurlan is a builder but he also earns by reselling fruit. He started reselling fruit four years ago with initial investment of 8,000 soms. His monthly income is 6,000 soms. He is applying for a loan in order to expand his business through expansion of his turnover. In the near future, he is planning to purchase a house, car and everything for his house and family. 

Nurzhan A. is thirty-eight and married. She has two children and both of them go to school. Now, she helps her sister sell clothes. She started this business with her sister three years ago with an initial investment of 15,000 soms. Now, she earns 7,000 soms. She wants to start her own business and start selling clothes independent of her sister. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase clothes for resale purposes. In the near future, she is planning to reinvest all her profits in her business and purchase some day furniture for her house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase chickens

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a married man with one child who attends school. His wife is employed as a sales representative and she helps in supporting the family. He has been operating his retail shop for the last two years, selling to town dwellers and passersby.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, a sack of rice and sugar and bottles of drinking water. In addition he works at the Kenya ferry services as his other source of income.

George faces the major challenge of inflation in his business. He hopes that in future he will be able to run a wholesale shop and improve his standard of living.

He decided to work with Yehu so as to get a loan to boost his business. He owns a house with electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase  wheat flour, maize flour, a sack of rice and sugar and bottles of drinking water.

loans.name: Myagmardorj

texts.en:
Myagmardorj T. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Hovd province, Mongolia. He and his family all live together in their 'ger,' a Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His two older children attend secondary school while his young daughter is in a local kindergarten. His wife is an employee in the canned food industry. 

Myagmardorj owns his own car and is a taxi driver in his town. He began his business in 2004 and has gained a lot of business experience. In addition, he also sells variety of grocery products such as vegetables and meats during autumn and winter months to supplement his earnings.  He says, "My children are still at a young age, but I need to save money for my children's future education from now on. " 

Myagmardorj is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to make necessary repairs and replace parts for his taxi as well as to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.use: repair taxi and buy spare parts for it

loans.name: Felipa's Group

texts.en:
Felipa T. is from the village of Leron, Buguey, Cagayan. She is 49 years old. Felipa is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Felipa is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Felipa owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Felipa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Felipa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felipa is requesting a loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Felipa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah B. lives in the Kitawuluzi neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has six children, all of whom are in school. Hadjah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medication.
Hadjah has a business selling fruits and vegetables. She has been in this business for over ten years, and she works seven days a week. Hadjah sells her fruits and vegetables in Owino market on a retail basis. She also generates additional income through selling Irish potatoes. Hadjah has requested a loan of 600,000 UGX from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more baskets of fruits and vegetables such as mangoes, oranges, pineapples and cabbages.
The main business challenge for Hadjah is seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow larger and to start selling wholesale only. She decided to join MCDT SACCO because she wanted additional capital.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables such as oranges, cabbages, tomatoes and mangoes

loans.name: Rizaldy

texts.en:
Rizaldy P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 45 years old and single. To make a living, Rizaldy owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rizaldy has been engaged in his business for over 20 years.
Rizaldy joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Rizaldy is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business and financially support immediate members of his family.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Nyamdorj

texts.en: Nyamdorj T. is a 45-year-old married man who lives with his wife and five children in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Two of his children attend a local secondary school. His wife works in the health sector and Nyamdorj works as a taxi driver. He began his business in 2006 after operating a meat-trading business for the previous three years. His previous business earnings plus his wife's salary have enabled him to buy his own car. Nyamdorj is a very optimistic and hardworking person who hopes to have his own house with a fence for his family. He is requesting a 1,600,000 MNT loan in order to purchase spare parts for his car and to purchase more meat for resale.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his car

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Roda N. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 30 years old. Roda is married and has two children, aged 3 and 1. To make a living, Roda raises crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Roda says she works hard to provide for her family and save for her children's future education.

Roda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Roda is requesting a new loan of 17,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Lucel

texts.en: Lucel P. is from the village of Upper Puntod. She is 27 years old. Lucel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lucel provides transportation services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Lucel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Lucel is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Lucel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Tursun's Group

texts.en: Tursun S. is leader of the group. She is 57 and married. She has three children. Her elder son is 26, her daughters are 24 and 22. Her elder son works in Russia and her daughters are going to graduate from an institution of higher education. Her husband is a farmer. She breeds cattle with the help of her husband. She started cattle breeding 39 years ago after her marriage with a purchase of cattle for 4,000 soms. For now, she could increase her turnover to 135,000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase fuels and lubricants in order to prepare hay for the cattle. In the near future, she is planning to marry off her son and daughters. Group members: Zhyparinca T. is treasurer of the group. She is 31 and married. She has four children. Her sons are 12, 10 and 6 years old and her daughter is 4 years old. Her two elder sons go to school and her two youngest children are at home. Her husband works in Russia. She breeds cattle. She started cattle breeding 10 years ago when her husband sent from Russia to Kyrgyzstan 12,000 soms. She purchased cattle. For now, she could purchase a house and cattle on the profits from cattle breeding and increase her profits to 3,000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to make capital repairs to her house before the winter period. In the near future, she is planning to give her children a higher education and increase cattle quantity. Meilikan E. is 38 and a widow. She has five children. Her daughters are 19 and 8 years old and her sons are 17, 14 and 12 years old. Her elder daughters work as shop assistants and all the other children go to school. Meilikan sells rice in the local market. She started 17 years ago with a purchase of a sack of rice for 165 soms. For now, she could increase her turnover to 76,400 soms and her profits to 4,300 soms. In line with selling rice, Meilikan is a farmer. Her children help her with farming in their free time. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase fuel and lubricants to prepare the soil for sowing. In the near future, she plans to provide for her children and give them a higher education. Meerimgul T. is 25 and married. She has three children. Her son is 6 years old and her daughters are 4 and 1. All her children are at home now. Her husband is a constructor. She is a farmer. She started farming four years ago with the purchase of a plot for 10,500 soms and began sowing rice. For now, she could start construction of her house, purchase cattle and increase her monthly income to 3,000 soms. She decided to breed cattle. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle for breeding. She is planning to continue construction of her house and to increase cattle quantity. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and lubricants in order to prepare hay for cattle

loans.name: Oyundelger

texts.en:
Oyundelger B. is a 36-year-old married woman who lives with her husband and three children in Hentiy province, central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest two daughters, aged 21 and 19, both attend a different university while her youngest son studies at a local high school. Her husband operates a taxi service for locals to supplement the family's income.
Oyundelger operates a meat trading business in her town by herself. She purchases a variety of meats from the local market and sells the products in Huchit Shonhor market, one of the largest markets in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She has monthly sales of approximately 2,750,000 MNT. Her husband earns between 15,000 and 25,000 MNT per day from his taxi business. Oyundelger's business currently operates at a stable level and she continues to make progress. The operating cost of her business is around 9,000 MNT and her monthly net profit reaches 490,000 MNT. In addition, she owns three houses which she lets out, for which she receives an extra income of 100,000 MNT per month from each house in rent.
Oyundelger hopes to grow her business in the future and continue her success. She says, "All I want is to provide a higher education for my children." Oyundelger is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan. She will use 1,800,000 MNT to purchase more meat in order to increase her sales, and the rest to remodel her house.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Rona

texts.en:
Rona M. is 32 years old, married and has three school-aged children that she dreams will finish college someday. She is from the town of Santo Niño, a part of South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. Rona is a farmer who plants and harvests rice to sell.

Rona joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is now requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to pay school tuition fees for her children and improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria C. is 51 years old, married and has two adult-aged children. She is from the town of Santo Niño, a part of South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. Victoria is a farmer who plants and harvests rice to sell. She has been a farmer for over 26 years.

Victoria joined CEVI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is now requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP that will be used to purchase farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use all additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Dorjsuren

texts.en:
Dorjsuren S. is 52 years old and a widow who lives with three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her children live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent owned by her daughter-in-law and surrounded by a fence. Her oldest son is in bad health and so stays at home. Her youngest son attends a university for defense force while her daughter has recently graduated from her university and is employed as a designer for a private company.

Dorjsuren operates a clothing business in a rented workplace next to a silk market where she makes a variety of clothing. She started her clothing business in 2007 and because the clothing has been so popular, she has been able to hire an assistant. Her business is in a popular spot that attracts many customers. She is a very responsible and hardworking person and says, " All I want is to help complete my son's education." Dorjsuren is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to enlarge her home's fence and to pay her son's tuition fees.

loans.use: To pay her son's tuition fees

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret N. lives in the Kitawuluzi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is divorced and has three children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (nephews, nieces and her mother).   

Margret has a business of making envelopes for photographs.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works six days out of every week. Margret sells both retail and wholesale.  Margret has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner MCDT SACCO which she will use to buy papers and glue. The main business challenge for Margret is seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations include buying another plot of land.   She decided to join MCDT because of the low interest rate charged.  

Margret lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medications.

loans.use: To buy more papers and glue.

loans.name: Sharapat's Group

texts.en:
Sharapat S. is the leader of this group. She is 46 years-old and married. She has three daughters of 18, 11 and eight years-old.  Her elder daughter is a student and her youngest daughters also go to school. Her husband is a taxi driver. Sharapat breeds cattle and she started cattle breeding two years ago with the purchase of cattle for 8,000 soms.  At present,, she would like to increase the quantity of her cattle and she is applying for a loan in order to do so.   In the near future, she plans to widen the cattle shed.
 
Other group members:

Elnura K. is the treasurer of this group. She is 24 years-old and married. She has a daughter of five years-old and a son of three years-old.  Both of them are still at home. Her husband is the logistics manager at the local school.  Elnura is a teacher at the local school.  Their main source of income is their salaries. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase a refrigerator.  In the near future, they are planning to purchase their own house because for now, they rent a house. 

Zulfiia K. is 21 years-old and married.  Her husband is a bee keeper and she keeps bees together with her husband. From the profits from bee keeping, they have been able to purchase cattle for breeding. They started bee keeping two years ago with an initial investment of 40,000 soms.  Zulfiia has applied for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle for breeding.  For now, they plan to purchase furniture for their house on the profits from bee keeping. In the future, they are planning to purchase an automobile for their family. 

Iniiat S. is 60 years-old and married. She has two sons, 30 and 23 years-old and two daughters 39 and 17 years-old.  Her husband is a veterinarian. Iniiat breeds cattle and her husband helps her in his free time. She started cattle breeding five years ago with an initial investment of 16,000 soms. Her monthly income is 3,000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to increase the quantity of cattle. In the near future,she is planning to pay for the marriage of her eldest son. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF).  MBF is a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married, with four children, to a hotel supplier.  All the children attend school.  For the last two years, she has been operating her business of supplying detergents. She sells from door to door to her neighbours and also to passers-by.

With the loan of Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase a bundle of detergents.  Her other source of income comes from her husband’s salary. 

Her major challenge in the business is high transportation costs as she travels from door to door. Her major goal is to get enough money to raise her family. She decided to join Kiva partner Yehu in order to get a loan to boost her business.

Rose owns a home with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of detergents.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline M. and her husband, Noel, have always dreamed of having a stable business to improve their meager income. The couple has four children – the eldest is thirteen years of age and the youngest and only daughter is two years old. The family depends on Noel's income from driving a tricycle (a motorcycle with attached sidecar for passengers) to meet their daily financial needs.
Life has been difficult for the couple but they did not lose hope that someday an opportunity would come their way. In 2008, Evangeline heard of an organization promoting a program that gives opportunity to poor women like her. Inspired by a desire to help and support her husband, Evangeline joined the organization – Kiva partner, Ahon sa Hirap, Inc., in the Philippines – to have access to capital to buy a motorcycle for her husband. Gladly, after almost three years they owned the tricycle and Noel's income increased. Today, Evangeline is applying for a loan of 25,000 PHP to use as starting capital to set up a store, which she will manage, selling motorcycle parts. She is so excited to start this business because she believes that this is the instrument for fulfilling their dreams for their children. The family is so happy that there are people and institutions that give chances to families who are full of hopes and dreams.

loans.use: To buy motorcycle parts for resale

loans.name: Nurkan Asanova's Group

texts.en:
Nurkan A. is leader of this group. She is 40 years old and married. She has four children: her sons are 17 and 15 years old and her daughters are 11 and 5 years old. Her three elder sons go to school and her youngest daughter is at home. Her husband works in construction. By education, Nurkan is a nurse and she opened a private medical center. She also breeds cattle because her parents gave her cattle and she decided to start cattle breeding. She now wants to provide her family members with an income from the medical center whilst significantly increasing her quantity of cattle. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase more cattle for breeding. She plans to purchase a car and make repairs to her house with her future profits. 
The other group members
Rahatkan B. is the treasurer of the group. She has eight children: her sons are 31, 27, 26, 24 and 20, and her daughters are 33, 30 and 17. All her children, except her youngest daughter, live independently of their parents. Her youngest daughter lives with her husband and Rahatkan. She sells vegetables at the local market. She started 15 years ago selling onions that she purchased for 500 KGS. Now she wants to increase her turnover, marry her children, purchase furniture for her house and increase her income to 8,000 KGS. She is planning to increase her turnover further and therefore she is applying for a loan. In the near future, she plans to diversify her assortment of vegetables, marry her youngest son, and give her daughter an opportunity to receive a higher education abroad. 
Uulkan D. is 57 and a widow. She has six children: her sons are 31, 25 and 17 years old and her daughters are 29, 22 and 8 years old. Her elder daughters and sons are married and live independently; her youngest daughter and son go to school. Uulkan breeds cattle. She started cattle breeding three years ago with an initial investment of 8,000 KGS. Now, she wants to increase her quantity of cattle and make repairs to her house. Her monthly income is 5,000 KGS. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase more cattle. In the near future, she plans to widen her cattle shed, increase her quantity of cattle, and give her son a higher education. 
Gulzhan U. is 45 years old and married. She has five children: her sons are 24 and 5 years old and her daughters are 27, 20 and 13 years old. Only two of her children live with her, the others live independently. Her husband is a logistics manager at the local school and also teaches physical culture. Gulzhan sells clothes and shoes. Three years ago, she purchased clothes and shoes with the help of a loan for 25,000 KGS. Now, she wants to increase her profits to 5,000 KGS. She is applying for a loan in order to increase her turnover. In the near future, she is planning to purchase her own container in order not to pay for rent. 

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Togoo

texts.en:
Togoo B. lives with her husband and nineteen year-old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter, Sarnai, attends a university. Togoo manages a traditional Mongolian shoe-making business.  She began her business by producing traditional boots in 1999, and has built a stable business operation. Her products are very popular among her customers due to their good quality and unique style, and she has gained many permanent customers, especially from neighboring countrysides. She makes her boots in her mother-in-law's home. She has made and stored a large quantity of children's boots.  

Togoo’s earnings have enabled her to raise her standard of living as well as expand her business. Moreover, she has used her earnings to purchase a new house with a fence.  She is a very hardworking woman who says "Now, I will make more traditional adult boots and store them for future sale." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to buy raw materials and grow her working capital.

loans.use: to buy raw materials

loans.name: Nazgul's Group

texts.en:
Nazgul R. is the leader of the group. She is twenty-seven and married. She has a six-year-old son, who goes to kindergarten. Her husband is a taxi driver. She is a manager at the local kindergarten. Seven years ago, her parents gave her cattle and she decided to start a business breeding cattle. For now, she has been able to increase cattle quantity, purchase household appliances and computer and make capital repairs of her house. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle for breeding. 

In the future, she is planning to purchase a car for her family. 

Group members:

Nurgul T. is the treasurer of the group. She is thirty-six and married. She has four children: her two elder sons and daughter go to school and her youngest son is at home. She is an accountant. Two years ago, her parents gave her cattle and she started breeding cattle. She has been able to increase the number of cattle and make capital repairs of her house. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the near future, she is planning to widen shed for cattle.

Bubusaira D. is forty-three and divorced. She has two daughters, aged fifteen and nine, both of whom go to school. She sells convenience goods at her own shop. She started seven years ago with initial investment of 200 soms. Before that, she sold convenience goods on a table near to her house. Day by day, she has been able to increase her turnover. For now, she could build a shop. She is applying for a loan in order to increase her turnover. 

Zamira Z. is thirty-four and married. She has three sons, aged fourteen, twelve and seven. Her husband works in construction. She sells vegetables at the local market. She started five years ago with financial support of her husband in the amount of 500 soms. Then, her business became profitable. She increased her turnover and was able to purchase household appliances. She is applying for a loan in order to increase her turnover further. In the future, she is planning to diversify the assortment of goods.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Lubov is married. She is a vendor in one of the grocery marketplaces in her home town of Stryi. She offers a variety of grocery items that are always in demand, such as cereal, sugar, noodles, tea, canned food, etc. She has been in the market for 10 years, and makes about 10,000 Grivnyas of gross income every month.  

Lubov is requesting a loan of 13,500 Grivnyas to increase her working capital. She can be characterized as a reliable and trustworthy borrower. The consistent growth of her small trade is solid proof of her balanced and reasonable entrepreneurial endeavors.

loans.use: to increase her working capital

loans.name: Andryi

texts.en:
Andryi is married with a 10-year-old daughter. His family lives in Ivano-Frankivsk. He works as a taxi driver and offers transportation services in the Ukraine. He has been in this business for 8 years, and his current monthly income is about 5,000 Grivnyas.  

Andryi is a very determined and hard-working man – he sometimes works 24 hours a day. He is trying to invest all his energy in his venture, thereby keeping it profitable and sustainable. He is hoping to receive a loan of 7,500 Grivnyas to install bio-methane gas equipment in his vehicle. A more reliable car that helps him bring down his running costs will enable him to serve more clients, handle tough competition and expand his business. Profits generated will not only promote continued growth of his business but also provide a good income for his family and help him pay back his car loan.

loans.use: to install bio-methane gas equipment in his vehicle

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old married woman and mother of 3 young children who still attend school. In 2009, she has decided to open a mini-market in her town. Her new business is essential to help her husband with the heavy expenses. She offers variety of products to her clients such as dairy products, food products, and detergents as per their needs. Today, she is requesting to borrow $500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her store’s inventory before the coming holidays. 

It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets, selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, store owners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships are an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

loans.use: to increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Nurgul's Group

texts.en: Nurgul T. is the leader of this group. She is forty-three and married. Her husband is builder. Nurgul sews toshoki (national patchwork quilts), blankets and pillows and sells them at the local market. She started four years ago with the purchase of a sewing machine for 5,000 soms. Now, she has been able to pay for her son’s marriage and has increased her income to 4,000 soms monthly. Nurgul is applying for a loan in order to purchase fabrics and materials used in the sewing process and, in this way, increase her turnover and her profits. In the future, she wants to purchase a car and renew her furniture. The other group members are: Cholponai A. is treasurer of the group. She is thirty-nine and married with two children, both of them going to school. Her husband is a builder. Cholponai buys furniture wholesales and resells it at a higher price. She started this business one year ago with an initial investment of 5,000 soms following a suggestion of her husband. With the profits from her business, she has been able to educate her son and increase her income to 1,000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to increase her turnover. In the near future, she wishes to expand her business, make capital repairs to her house, see her son married, and purchase a car. Damira K. is thirty-five and married with three children: two of them go to school and one of them is at home. Her husband is a builder. Damira is a masseuse at the orphanage. Now, she wants to start cattle breeding. She doesn’t have sufficient funds and therefore, she is applying for a loan. In the near future, she plans to purchase a house and cattle for breeding. Saltanat B. is twenty-seven and married with three children. Her husband is a builder. Saltanat works in a factory that produces leather. One year ago, she decided to start cattle breeding with an initial investment of 5,000 soms. Now, she has been able to purchase furniture for her house with the help of her business and increase her income to 6,000 soms. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle and to make repairs to her kitchen. In the near future, she want to purchase household appliances in order to improve her living conditions. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members.  Sarah has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for a few years, and she works one day every week.  Sarah sells her products from home, by means of retail.  Sarah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.  She also generates additional income through selling sand.  The main business challenge for Sarah is transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to buy a plot so that she can build rental rooms.  She decided to join MCDT because it was helping poor women to access credit.  Sarah lives in a home that she owns.  She doesn't have access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina is a small market entrepreneur from Novaya Kahovka. She is a divorcee. Valentina raises two children– a 19-year-old son Dmitryi and a 7-year-old daughter Elvira. With two children to care for, she works really hard to make ends meet. Valentina launched her knitted wear sales business 17 years ago. To date, she has already invested about 50,000 Grivnyas in this trade. Her turnover capital amounts to 40,000 Grivnyas. Monthly net profit amounts to 8,000 Grivnyas.
