texts.es: El Señor Jorge Antonio tiene 29 años y tiene1 hijo menor de edad a su cargo. él desde muy pequeño salió de su casa, para dedicarse a brindar el servicio de soladura y pintado, pero ahora se encuentra muy agotado Jorge trabaja actualmente desde hace mas de 7 años el negocio es rentable por la alta cantidad de personas que solicitan este servicio por la facilidad, rapidez y eficiencia. El cliente es la segunda vez que obtiene un préstamo de nuestra institución es por eso que solicita este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima.
texts.en:
Jorge Antonio, 29 has a minor son in his care. Julio left home very young to work as a welder and painter. He is currently very tired. He has worked in this very profitable business because of the large number of customers who request services thanks to his speed, efficiency and ease for over 7 years. This is his 2nd loan request from our institution and the funds will be used to buy raw materials.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Miguel Ángel

texts.es: El señor Miguel Ángel A. R., tiene 51 años de edad el es casado y tienen 2 hijos el mayor de edad estudia su carrera universitaria  la cual es Periodismo y el menor esta en preescolar, el señor Ampié labora como conductor de un recorrido escolar, fue su papa quien lo ingreso a esta actividad pues el señor sobrevivía de la misma manera, él y su familia habitan en un humilde hogar, al cual desea remodelar sus condiciones y es por esta razón que solicita un préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción que le permitan la edificación de un muro perimetral y de esta forma protegerlo de los antisociales que amenazan la seguridad de su familia, esta inversión le brindara al señor A. la tranquilidad de que su familia habita en un lugar, cómodo, y seguro. Ellos son una familia trabajadora que se ha abierto paso gracias al apoyo que les a brindado en varias ocaciones Afodenic, por tanto dicen sentirse agradecidos por apoyarles a mejorra dia a dia sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Miguel Ángel A. R. is 51 and married. They have 2 grown children. The eldest is in university, studying journalism. The youngest is in pre-school. Miguel works as a driver on a school route. His father got him into this work, as he survived on this work as well. Aguilar and his family live in a small home, which he wants to remodel. For this reason, he is requesting a loan for the purchase of construction materials that will allow him to build a wall around the perimeter in order to protect it from the antisocial elements that menace the security of his family. This investment will provide A. with peace, knowing that his family is living in a comfortable and safe place. They are a hard-working family that has made its way thanks to the help that Afodenic has given them on several occasions. They are grateful for the support in daily improving their living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: building a wall around the perimeter

loans.name: Lorena Monica

texts.es:
Mónica de 30 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil lugar caracterizado por su montañas y caminos de tierra. Ella vende almuerzos todos los días para poder mantener a su familia.    

Comenzó con el negocio de almuerzos para poder ayudar con los gastos familiares, vende comidas típicas en los almuerzos como caldo de bola, caldo de pata, arroz con pollo etc. Tiene un promedio de 60 clientes al día que le compran los almuerzos. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar una cocina industrial para hacer mas platos ya que ahora solo esta cocinando en su cocina pequeña. En el futuro quiere tener su propio restaurante y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Mónica, 30, lives in a periurban area of Paraíso in Guayaquil, a place notable for its hills and unpaved streets. She sells lunches daily to support her family. She started the lunch business to help with family expenses. She sells typical dishes at lunch like: caldo de bola (stuffed plantain balls soup), caldo de pata (beef hoof soup), chicken and rice, etc. She serves 60 customers daily on average. She wants to use the loan to buy an industrial stove so that she can make more meals since she is currently cooking on a small stove. In the future she’d like to have her own restaurant and expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For an industrial stove.

loans.name: Ángela

texts.es: La señora Ángela E. M. tiene la edad de 53 años , habita acompañada de su pareja de vida, ellos tienen 3 hijos mayores de edad de los cuales el mayor le ayuda en su negocio y el de en medio labora independientemente y la menor estudia la primaria, ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas desde hace mas de 7 años, ellos habitan en un humilde hogar que ha construido con mucho esfuerzo y edificado desde hace años atrás, es para su vivienda que solicita un préstamo para la compra de materiales para enladrillar el piso de su casa e instalar portones de hierro para ofrecerle una mayor seguridad a su casa y proteger a su familia de los antisociales que amenazan con la seguridad de los habitantes del barrio donde habitan.
texts.en:
Ángela E. M. is 53. She lives with her life partner. They have 3 grown children. The eldest helps in her business, the middle child works independently and the youngest is in elementary school. Angela has sold tortillas for over 7 years. They live in a small home which they worked very hard to build and they have been working on it for several years since. She is requesting this loan for her home, for the purchase of materials to lay bricks on the floor of her home and install wooden doors to provide better security and protect her family from the antisocial elements that menace the security of the residents of her neighbourhood.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: home remodeling

loans.name: Diana Marbely

texts.es:
Diana Marbely vive con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos menores de edad,  inició con una experiencia de más de 2 años, emprendió un negocio de pulpería, hasta que decidió independizarse e iniciar su negocio trabaja todos los días. 
Ya que pone mucho empeño en mejorar cada día la atención con sus clientes Con su crédito planea comprar golosinas, refrescos, jugos, granos básicos y detergentes. Su meta es adquirir más inventario para ofrecer y ver realizados a sus hijos a nivel profesional y especialmente vinculados exitosamente a una gran empresa.
texts.en:
Diana Marbely lives with her husband and two young children. With over 2 years of experience in a general store, she decided to become independent and start her business. She works every day. She is dedicated to improving her customer service every day. With her loan she will purchase candies, pop, juice, basic grains and detergents. Her goals are to acquire more inventory, and to see her children reach a professional level, especially to be linked successfully to a large company.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Nueva Ilusión (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Nueva Ilusión se encuentra formada por un grupo de 10 mujeres quienes  luchan  día a día para mejorar la economía de sus hogares y entregar a sus hijos un mejor futuro. Viven en la parroquia de Cumbe, esta parroquia es de clima frió, la actividad económica de este sector es la agricultura y ganadería, mucha de su población sale a la ciudad  en busca de mejores trabajos para así mejorar la economía de sus hogares.

La Señora Carmen vive en el barrio Tres de Noviembre en la parroquia de Cumbe. Este es el primer crédito que realiza en la fundación y fue invitada por una amiga del barrio que pertenece a la banca comunal. Tiene 35 años,  es casada y tiene  2 hijos de 13 y 11 años de edad. Su primer hijo estudia en un colegio de la ciudad y su segundo hijo  en una escuela de la parroquia. Su esposo en busca de un mejor futuro para sus hijos ha migrado  y con su trabajo ayuda a su familia. Tiene una casa pequeña que es de su propiedad pero vive en la casa de su mamá en donde comparten gastos.
Doña Carmen se dedica a la cría de animales, los cuyes y gallinas las que vende en su parroquia, tiene ganado y la leche es para entregar a los carros lecheros, se dedica esta labor hace 15 años, también se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar  y al cuidado de sus hijos. 
Su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de alimento para sus animales, su meta es  crecer en su negocio.

La Señora María Filomena vive por el barrio la Floresta en la parroquia de Cumbe, tiene 59 años, es casada y tiene 4 hijos de 39, 37, 25, 20 años de edad, todos sus hijos son casados y tres de ellos viven de manera independiente, solo su ultima hija vive en su casa y comparten los gastos del hogar. Su esposo trabaja como ayudante de albañil, gracias al trabajo han logrado construir su casa propia.
Doña María toda su vida se ha dedicado a la cría de animales como ganado, aves de corral y cuyes a los que los vende cuando tiene alguna necesidad económica. También labora en la agricultura, siembra maíz, hortalizas los que en su mayor parte es para el consumo de su hogar.
Este es su primer crédito que realiza en la banca comunal y fue  invitada por sus amigas del barrio que forman parte de este  grupo de mujeres luchadoras,  su primer crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de pollos para seguir en este negocio ya esa es su meta.
texts.en:
The Nueva Illusion ["New Hope"] community bank is a group of 10 women who fight day to day to improve their household incomes and offer their children a better future. They live in the Cumbe parish, a parish with a cold climate whose main economic activities are agriculture and ranching. The majority of the population leaves for the city in search of better work to improve their household income. Carmen lives in the Tres de Noviembre neighbourhood in the Cumbe parish. This is her first loan with the Fundacion. She was invited by a friend in the neighbourhood who belongs to the community bank. She is 35, married and has 2 children ages 13 and 11. Her oldest child studies in a school in the city, and her second child goes to a school in the parish. Her husband migrated, looking for a better future for his children, and he helps the family with his work. She has a small home of her own, but she lives in her mother's home where they share costs. Carmen raises animals; guinea pigs and hens that she sells in her parish. She has cattle, and she provides the milk to milk trucks. She has been doing this work for 15 years. She also does the household chores and cares for her children. Her loan is to be invested in the purchase of food for her animals. Her goal is to grow her business. Maria Filomena lives in the Floresta neighbourhood in the Cume parish. She is 59, married and has 4 children ages 39, 37, 25 and 20. All of her children are married and three of them live independently. Only her youngest daughter lives with her, and they share the household costs. Her husband works as a bricklayer's assistant, and thanks to his work they have been able to build their own home. All of her life, Maria has raised animals such as livestock, barnyard fowl and guinea pigs, which she sells when she has financial needs. She also works in agriculture. She grows corn and vegetables, the majority of which are for her household consumption. This is her first loan in the community bank, and she was invited by her friends in the neighbourhood who are part of this hard-working women's group. She will invest this, her first loan, in the purchase of chickens to continue with this business, which is her goal.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase food for animals and chickens

loans.name: Las Progresistas De Cupiche Group

texts.es:
Alcancia Comunal “Las Progresistas de Cupiche” este conforman ocho integrantes dedicados al comercio y al servicio de lavandería del transporte interprovincial, 

Ynes Gladis C. con 39 años, es la tesorera de esta Alcancía Comunal . casada, con dos hijos dependientes, Ynes de dedica al servicio de lavandería de carros interprovinciales que llegan de distintos lugares del interior de Perú (Huánuco; Pasco, Huancayo, Pucallpa, Tingo Maria, etc), lleva 10 años haciendo este servicio; asimismo hace tres años, se dedica a realizar y elaborar tejido artesanal a palitos y crochett,  como medias, ponchos, chompas, etc,  ofreciendo estas prendas al por mayor y menor; se animó a elaborar estos tejidos, con las intenciones de poder colaborar con su esposo, quien trabaja realizando servicios de transporte, con un carrito alquilado que ha diario le da para los gastos del día pero no lo suficiente,  asi ambos aportan en su hogar para mejorar su economía. Las ganancias que ella obtiene, las invierte 
en los estudios de sus dos hijos, uno de ellos lleva preparándose para postular a la Universidad.
 Esta familia anhela mucho adquirir una movilidad propia que le ayude a mejorar su ingresos económicos, además comprar una maquina de cocer, lanas, hilos, agujas, o otros materiales que le son útiles para su trabajo, la Alcancia Comunal “Las Progresistas de Cupiche”, están agradecidos por el préstamo otorgado y aseguran pagar sus cuotas puntualmente.
texts.en:
The “Las Progresistas de Cupiche” communal bank has 8 members; some are merchants and others provide a car wash service for interprovincial buses. Ynes Gladis C., 39, is group Treasurer. She’s married and has two dependent children. She provides a car wash service for interprovincial cars that arrive from various points in the Peruvian interior (Huánuco, Pasco, Huancayo, Pucallpa, Tingo Maria, etc.). She has been providing this service for 10 years. Three years ago she started to make artisanal knitting and crochet works like socks, ponchos, sweaters, etc. that she sells at wholesale and retail. She was motivated to go into crafts with the intention of helping her husband, who works in transport with a leased car and barely earns enough for daily expenses, so that both of them could contribute to improving their family income. Thanks to her earnings they can pay for their two children’s education; one of them is getting ready to seek admission to the University. This family very much wants to acquire a vehicle of their own that will help them improve income in addition to buying a sewing machine, wools, threads, needles and other materials that are useful for her work. The members of the “Las Progresistas de Cupiche” communal bank are grateful for the loan granted and assure its prompt repayment.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine, wools, threads, needles and other materials.

loans.name: Agapito

texts.en:
Agapito C. is from the village of Tagodalo, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 53 years old. Agapito is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Agapito raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting, harvesting, and selling squash and other vegetables. Agapito is just starting this business.

In 2008, Agapito joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agapito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Agapito is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer. This loan will be Agapito's fourth loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation.  Because manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template that allows the Field Partners to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Glorie

texts.en:
Glorie E. is from the village of Tabuan, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 41 years old. Glorie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Glorie makes and sells food. The main source of income comes from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Glorie has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Glorie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glorie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This loan will be Glorie's second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation.  Because manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template that allows the Field Partners to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna T. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 40 years old. Lorna is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a pedicab transport service. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lorna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to repair an existing vehicle. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be Lorna's third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation.  Because manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template that allows the Field Partners to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda C. is from the village of Bayabas, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 43 years old. Luzminda is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Luzminda operates a tricycle transport service. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $195 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Luzminda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to repair her vehicle for better service.

She is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be her 11th loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Basiliza

texts.en:
This is Basiliza S., 53, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Maximiano S., who is also her business partner. She is the mother of their six children, five of whom are already working and are settled down with their own families, while the youngest is currently enrolled in college. By the grace of God, Basiliza has managed to support her youngest child's schooling up to the college level. At this time, she is working hard to continue sending her youngest to college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Basiliza, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Basiliza operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and sell them piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, electronic phone load, and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $5 to $7.50 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Basiliza dreams to be able to give her youngest child a quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia V. is from the village of Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old and married with five adult-aged children. To make a living, Celia runs a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Celia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Agustina G. is from Barangay 4, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 33 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she provides motorcycle transport to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $105 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Agustina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina T. is from the village of Nabbotuan, Solana, Cagayan. She is 50 years old, married, and has eight adult-aged children. To make a living, she raises pigs for breeding. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Josefina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. 

Josefina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 6th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Kenanga Indah Group

texts.en: Ni Komang A. S. is a 35-year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali. She is the group leader of this sixteen-member group loan offered by MUK. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Kenanga Indah (PK-10302). Ni Komang is married and has one school-aged child. She owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 150,000 IDR a month. In 2010, Ni Komang joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 1,500,000 IDR which will be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. The loan will be her first from MUK. Ni Komang plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About MUK: The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives. ***************************************************** Ni Komang A. S. (0) merupakan 35 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali. Ni Komang adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 16 anggota. Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar. Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Kenanga Indah (PK-10302). Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dA. beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Komang sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dA. 5 tahun. DA. kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Komang menghasilkan sekitar 150,000 IDR. Dalam 2010, Ni Komang bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Komang meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dA. MUK. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,500,000 IDR. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dA. MUK. Tentang MUK: Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehA.-hA..

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie S. is from the village of Barcolan. She is 46 years old. Virgie is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Virgie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Virgie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells her raised animal.

In 2006, Virgie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Virgie is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Virgie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Ganbat

texts.en:
Ganbat P. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. All his three son attend university. His wife runs a used clothes selling business at a local market to supplement for her family's income. Ganbat started and has been operating this wood products producing business since 1983. He builts frame for Ger's complete with ornaments and exports them to Buriad, a city in Russia. 

He has used his business earnings to pay for his children's tuition fees. In the 27 years of owning his business, Ganbat has not only gained experience and knowledge in making quality furniture products, but he has also gained business knowledge. He is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to grow his working capital for his business.

loans.use: To buy more wood

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda G. is from the village of Barcolan. She is 37 years old. Yolanda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Yolanda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Yolanda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 22000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Yolanda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Nurzhan

texts.en:
Nurzhan O. is 40 years old, married and has four children. Her husband works as an electrician and supports Nurzhan with the household. 
In 1995, Nurzhan began to engage in stock-breeding using her 5,000 KGSsavings and bought only her first calf. Also, she decided to engage in cultivating land with potatoes. 

Nurzhan is a real hard-working woman and is striving to provide her children with a better life leaded to success.  Today she has two milk cows,  two calves and a small barn for her cattle, whose milk she sells to her customers at the local market,.  

Nurzhan will use this loan of 35,000 KGS to further broaden her business by buying one more cow. She expects for increasing the sales of milk and also to acquire new customers. With the revenues, she plans to provide a good education to her children. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Alma's Group

texts.en:
Alma M. is from the village of Sampaguita, Solana, Cagayan. She is 45 years old. Alma is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Alma is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Alma owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP whenever she sells one of her raised animals.

In 2010, Alma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase medication for her livestock. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Alma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Nasema is the group leader of Baqry group. She is 45 years old. She is married with three children and lives in 16th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She has two sons and one daughter and they are students at school.

Nasema wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. She wants to buy necessary materials for her business and wants to make her new shop larger and buy a new machine as well. She hopes to expand and progress her business and to have more clients.

Nasema thanks AFS and all Kiva lenders for this loan process in Afghanistan.

She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marife is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her fourth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. He has been farming for forty years and has employed one farmhand. His main products are milk and maize, which he sells at a local market. He is 67 years old and is married with 10 children who are all adults. Two of the children attend school.

Gabriel has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The income from the sale of milk will enable him to pay school fees for his children. He aspires to acquire four more dairy cows in five years' time.

His primary challenges are lack of constant labour and lack of feeds, due to unpredictable supply and prices. He is grateful to Juhudi for the financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. He has been farming for twenty years and has employed two farmhands. His mixed farm produces maize, bananas, and milk, which he sells locally. He also earns income from his rental houses in the same location. John is 63 years old. He is married with seven adult children. One of the children attends school.

John has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 45,000 KES to purchase and insure a  dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to improve his family's quality of life and expand his business. In the future, he would like to increase the number of his dairy cows and start a business of selling animal feeds. He also aspires to start raising poultry as well.

His major challenge has been lack of enough land to plant nappier grass, so he has to lease land elsewhere.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

texts.en:
Julius R. is 37 years of age, is married to Irine Kobilo, and is the father of a boy aged 14. Julius operates a small-scale horticultural farm. He resides in Kapkiamo a few kilometers from Kabarnet town.

Julius has borrowed a loan of Kshs 30,000; he intends to use Kshs 1,000 to purchase tomatoes, Kshs 3,000 to purchase tree seedlings, Kshs 15,000 to purchase water pipes for irrigation, Kshs 8,100 to purchase fertilizer and Kshs 2,900 to purchase insecticides.

Julius was introduced to KADET by an existing client. Most of his clients are residents of Kapkiamo and Kabarnet town. If this loan boosts his business, he intends to save his profits and later start dairy farming.

Julius describes himself has hardworking and ready to help his community.

Dinah has a cereals store where she earns her income. She has been in this business for the past twenty years with an income of Kshs 10,000 per month.

Dinah was introduced to KADET by a friend and is applying for her first loan of Kshs 20,000 with KADET. With this loan she plans to buy five bags of maize and four bags of beans.

Dinah hopes to operate a large cereal store where she will be able to supply foodstuffs to schools and sell the best quality to her customers. She also hopes, in the future, to extend the same services to the city centre.

loans.name: Caleb

texts.en:
Caleb has a mixed farm in Kisii town, western Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for ten years and has employed one farmhand. His main products are milk, sugarcane and maize which he sells locally. He also earns income from his rental houses in the same location.

Caleb is 52 years old and married with 4 children between the ages of 19 and 30. Two of the children attend school.

Caleb has requested this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo  to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this dairy cow will enable him to supply his family with enough milk for consumption and therefore reduce the expense of buying milk. The extra income from the sale of milk will be used to pay school fees for his children.

In future, he plans to improve his farming to large-scale farming and acquire two other dairy cows. His major challenges have been poor climatic conditions, lack of trustworthy workers, and delayed payment by the sugarcane companies. He says that Juhudi is doing good work by providing farmers with loans and should target people at grassroots so as to improve their lives.

loans.name: Osiemo

texts.en:
Osiemo is a farmer from Kisii town in western Kenya. He has been farming for ten years. His mixed farm produces maize, beans, milk and nappier grass which are sold locally. He is also employed as a  "matatu" (back-country bus) driver. He is 43 years old and married with 8 children who are between the ages of 4 and 25. Five of the children attend school.

Osiemo has requested this loan of 35,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help him expand his business and pay school fees for his children. In future, he would like to expand his business by acquiring five more dairy cows and also own a  "matatu".

His biggest challenge has been limited finances to purchase enough farm inputs like fertilizers and animal feed.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne A. O. is thirty-six years old. She is married and has three children aged between ten years old and four years old. Her business is located at Nyamasaria in a very business market in Kisumu along the Kisumu-Nairobi road. She sells building poles to private developers, construction workers and hardware shops. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is finding and paying for a means of transporting the poles. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more poles to expand her business and meet customer demand. In future, she hopes to diversify by opening a hardware shop. She describes herself as honest and self-motivated.

loans.use: Buying building poles for resale

loans.name: Phelesia

texts.en:
Phelesia A. O. is twenty-six years old. She is single and does not have any children yet. Her business is located at Nyamasaria in a very business market in Kisumu along a busy highway. She sells charcoal to the local people. Besides the charcoal business which she really likes, she sells second-hand clothes.  She says that she has been doing business for four years. She says that her businesses are profitable and the only major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her businesses doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more second-hand clothes to expand the clothes business as people are already buying clothes in anticipation for the christmas festivities. She sees herself growing her two businesses in the next five years and even diversifying to a restaurant business. She describes herself as patient and quiet.
