loans.name: Sang

texts.en:
Sang is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for ten years and has employed one farmhand. He sells his milk through Kenya Cooperative Creameries in Sotik town. He also earns income from the small-scale farming of tea which he sells through Kenya Tea Development Authority. He is also a carpenter in Cheborgei market.

Sang is 35 years old. He is married and has been blessed with 5 children who are between the ages of 1 and 12. Three of the children are currently in school.

He has requested this loan of 35,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He says that this loan will help improve his income from the sale of milk and enable him to meet the needs of his family. His major challenges are lack of knowledge about animal feed and diseases, and poor marketing and pricing. In future, he would like to expand his business and start a zero-grazing farm that will increase his production.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
63-year-old Josephine S. is requesting a loan through ASHI which will be used to enhance her pig raising business. She wants a larger amount of capital to be able to purchase more pigs. She started this business in 2004 in order to augment her husband’s income as a farmer. With their children’s needs, Josephine and her husband’s sporadic incomes are insufficient to be able to grow their businesses at the same time.

Starting her business with a few pigs to be raised and sold after a period of time, Josephine then became a member of ASHI where she has been able to obtain a loan, so her ability to raise more pigs has improved.  Her husband has been supporting her and has been partnering her in running the business. Out of the profit Josephine is making through her business, she has been able to support her grandchildren’s education and she hopes that her business will grow more in order to support her family’s dreams. 

Her long term goals are to have a full-fledged hog fattening business, to invest in her home, and to have a sustainable secondary farming business.

loans.use: To purchase additional hogs to raise.

loans.name: Crisanto

texts.en:
Crisanto E. is from the village of San Isidro. He is 31 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice to sell. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately $750 from each harvest.

In 2010, Crisanto joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for her university education fees

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Industrious, disciplined and hardworking are qualities that best describe Jocelyn B., a 42 year old. She is married to Rolando, a fisherman, and they were blessed with three children whose ages are 17, 9 and 8, a high school student and two elementary students.

It was the year 2004 when she became a member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. a partner micro-finance institution of KIVA in the Philippines. She is one of the good performing members of ASHI. Though she is active, she only borrows capital that she thinks she can regularly repay.  The family income is only enough for their daily needs and school expenses for their children. 

After seven long years she has gained confidence and is now applying for a loan of 17,000 PHP to buy additional fishing gear, nets and a canoe or wooden boat for her husband to use. She will also buy additional piglets for her hog raising business. Fishing and hog raising have been their primary sources of income for the past seven years, and they have really benefited from it. Their future plan is to develop these businesses more and make them stable so as to be able to sustain the education of their children. They also plan to renovate their current house and buy additional appliances.

Jocelyn is so glad that she became a member of ASHI and KIVA because their life has improved since then and their dream is now at hand. She hopes and prays that the two institutions will continue to support her goals for herself and her family.

loans.use: to buy piglets, fishing gears, nets and a canoe/wooden boat

loans.name: Floriza

texts.en:
Floriza J. is 39 years of age and is married to Ramon J.. They were blessed with three children whose ages are 23, 18 and 7. Unfortunately, they failed to send their two eldest children to college due to financial limitations. Their family income can only suffice to cover their daily consumption, and that is why the schooling of their children was limited to high school. Yet you can understand the determination of the couple to send their children to college to complete a degree. Both parents are hardworking and full of hopes and dreams; however, chances seldom come to them. 

That’s why in 2009 when the couple heard of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. a partner micro-finance institution of KIVA in the Philippines, Floriza immediately joined the program. Because of her dedication and commitment as a member, she was awarded several loans which she used in raising hogs. Now she is applying for another loan of 12,000 PHP to use as additional capital in her hog raising business. She plans to buy two more piglets and sacks of feed for them. 

She is hoping that this new capital will increase their profit so that she can earn for the schooling of her children and sustain their daily financial needs. Now that her skill in hog raising has developed, she plans to increase the number of pigs she is raising and build much better housing for them. She has plans for a piggery in the future. She is praying that the partnership of ASHI and KIVA will prosper so that she can have easy access to capital without collateral for her business plans.

loans.use: buy piglets and feed for them

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice is a fifty year old widow and the mother of four children. Three of the children have finished school and the youngest is currently in high school. She has been in the clothing business for a year now and also farms.

She learned about KADET LTD through her friend who has been an existing KADET LTD client. With this first loan Loice intends to purchase additional clothing to add to her current inventory so that she can meet her clients' demands. Her business is situated at a very strategic place in town so she has a good number of clients.

Her future plan is to buy a plot of land and develop rental houses.

loans.use: to purchase additional clothes to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth Aoko

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a forty-two-year-old mother of nine children, and she is married to Mr. O., who is a mechanic. She has been in the business of selling charcoal for ten years now and is the main supplier in her town. She says she makes a good profit out of the business and she has been able to educate three of her children using the profits from the business, and now they are employed doing different jobs.

With this third loan, Elizabeth plans to buy additional bags of charcoal so as to have enough stock to continue supplying her clients. Her future plan is to own a big store and become a wholesale supplier of charcoal.

loans.use: To purchase additional charcoal to resell

loans.name: Batchuluun

texts.en:
Batchuluun is a 50-year-old man who lives with his wife and five children in Ulaanbaatar (the capital city of Mongolia). His two eldest daughters are married but live in their parent’s house. The next daughter, Batchimeg, is a 20-year-old college student. Batchuluun’s eldest son, Amartuvshin, 18 years old, is a design upholsterer in an auto maintenance garage. His youngest son, Amarbayasgalan, 15 years old, attends a local secondary school. Batchuluun’s wife works in a carwash center as a washer. 

Batchuluun started his taxi business in 2007. He is one of Credit Mongol's reliable VIP customers. He has taken out a micro-loan twice and used it for building a house for his family. He is a very hardworking family-oriented man. This time he wants to fit the house with a local heating system before the winter. Therefore he needs to buy a special stove, boiler, pipes and some insulation materials. He has already done all the necessary calculations and found a person who installs heating systems. The loan Batchuluun is requesting will be used to buy materials for the heating system and insulation materials for the house.

loans.use: to buy materials for a heating system and insulation materials for the house

loans.name: Artemio

texts.en:
Artemio I. is from the village of San Isidro. He is 37 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice to sell. He has been engaged in his business for over twelve years and earns approximately $300 per harvest for these activities.

In 2010, Artemio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo Y. is from the village of San Isidro. He is 41 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice to sell. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty years and earns approximately $715 per harvest.

In 2010, Eduardo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 21,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth is an active member of Nkumari Group in Nkubu town, eastern Kenya. He has been farming for eight years. His mixed farm produces maize, beans and bananas which he sells to the local market. He also earns income from his carpentry services to the local market.

Kenneth is 32 years old and married with four children, ages 11, 9, 3 and 18 months. Two of the children attend school.

He has requested this loan of 50,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase water pipes for irrigation and fertilizers. He says that this loan will assist him upgrade his banana farm and improve his production. The proceeds from this project will help him pay school fees for his children and build a better house for his family. He hopes that in five years' time, he will have acquired two more dairy cows and expanded his banana plantation from one acre to three acres.

His biggest challenges have been pests and diseases, and also the high cost of transport.

loans.use: To purchase water pipes for irrigation and fertilizer.

loans.name: Celestino

texts.en:
Celestino Y. is from the village of San Isidro.  He is 53 years old.  Celestino is married and has two adult-aged children.  To make a living, Celestino owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops.  While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice.  Celestino has been engaged in his business for over 30 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Celestino joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celestino is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure.  This loan will be the first loan taken out by Celestino from ASKI.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Agapito

texts.en:
Agapito P. is from the village of San Isidro. He is 55 years old. Agapito is married and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Agapito owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Agapito has been engaged in his business for over 31 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Agapito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agapito is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Agapito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Né le 18 Novembre 1979 à Sikasso, Monsieur SAMAKE est marié et père des deux enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Mamassoni, un des quartiers péripheriques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur SAMAKE après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est finalement initié au domaine du commerce notamment à celui des matériels d’électricité depuis maintenant huit ans. Disposant  de sa propre Quincaillerie en face du Centre de Santé  de Référence C.S.REF « Trypano », il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux années. Après avoir correctement remboursés tous les quatre prêts précédents, il est à son cinquième prêt qui sera utilisé pour acheter, à Bamako, Bobo, Koumassi et Abidjan (respectivement au Mali, en Burkina Faso, au Ghana et en Côte d’Ivoire) 20 rouleaux de fil différents, une dizaine de rallonge, 30 cartons de contacteurs, 50 cartons d’ampoules différentes, 25 paires de réglettes, 20 paquets de disjoncteur, des prises etc. 
 Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 295 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on November 18, 1979 in Sikasso, Mr. Samaké is married and the father of two children. He lives with his family in Mamassoni, one of the outlying districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having tried out several businesses without success, Mr. Samaké finally started selling electrical equipment eight years ago. He is the owner of his hardware store opposite "Trypano", the main health care center, and is much sought after by his clientele due to the good quality of his products. In order to satisfy his ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. After having correctly repaid his previous four loans, he applied for his fifth loan to buy in Bamako, Bobo, Koumassi and Abidjan (in Mali, Burkina Faso, Ghana and Côte d'Ivoire, respectively) 20 rolls of various wires, 10 extensions, 30 boxes of contactors, 50 boxes of various light bulbs, 25 pairs of lighting strips, 20 boxes of circuit-breakers, plugs, etc. He expects to make a monthly profit of 295,000 CFA francs, which will essentially serve to contribute to covering family expenses, pay the interest on his loan and reinvest any remaining capital in his business.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electrical equipment for his hardware store

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita C. is from the village of Barcolan. She is 35 years old. Carmelita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Carmelita owns & operates a business venture in the services sector providing transportation services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating motorcycle transport business. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Carmelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to repair vehicle used in the business. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Carmelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Diakarya

texts.fr:
Né le 19 Avril 1977 à Sikasso, Monsieur Diakarya B. est marié et père de cinq enfant (2 garçons et 3 filles). Il réside avec sa famille à Sanoubougou II Extension, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Employé dans une compagnie d’assurance “SABU GNUMA”, Monsieur B. en plus de cette activité, dispose d’une quincaillerie il y a maintenant cinq  ans. 
Très apprécié et sollicité des entrepreneurs, promoteurs immobiliers etc, Diakarya reçoit beaucoup de commandes qu’il ne peut honorer faute de ressources financières.
Ainsi il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance de Soro Yiriwaso afin de mieux satisfaire les besoins de ses clients que ne cessent d’accroitre au fil du temps. 
Ce premier prêt lui permettra d’acheter auprès des grossistes de la ville, 5 cartons d’ampoules différentes, 20 rallonges, 3 cartons de contacteur, 2 cartons de peintures différentes, 2 paquets de colles “Super Glue”, 2 rouleaux de fil différents, 5 paires de réglettes, 4 paquets de disjoncteurs, 5 paquets de cadenas, etc. 
 Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born April 19, 1977 in Sikasso, Mr. Diakarya B. is a married father of five children, two boys and three girls. He lives with his family in Sanoubougou II Extension, a popular neighborhood in the village of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). Employed by the insurance company, Sabu Gnuma, Mr. B., in addition to this, has run a hardware store for the past five years. He is much appreciated and solicited by contractors, developers, etc., and he receives many requests for items he cannot supply due to limited financial resources. Thus he decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso in order to better satisfy the needs of his clients who continue to come over time. This first loan will allow him to buy from wholesalers in the city, five boxes of different bulbs, 20 extension cords, three boxes of contactors, two boxes of different paint, two packets of super glue, two rolls of different wire, five pairs of strips, four packs of CB's five packs of locks, etc. He envisions receiving a monthly profit of 200,000 Francs CFA with which he will use essentially for increasing his business, paying for family expenses, and to pay the interest on his first loan.

Translated from French by Katherine Evans, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies for his hardware store

loans.name: Rhona

texts.en:
Rhona N. lives in the Kisasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 7 children, six of whom are in school.     Rhona has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for seven years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Rhona sells from home, wholesale.    Rhona has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy firewood.    She also generates additional income through brick laying. 

The main business challenge(s) for Rhona include transportation.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are expanding the business.   Rhona lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy firewood for resale

loans.name: Karim

texts.fr:
Âge de 39 ans, Monsieur Karim K. est marié et père de cinq enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Bankoni, un des quartiers péripheriques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  K. après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié il 10 ans à la vente de matériels d’occasions  tels les pneus, jantes, etc.  
Il mène aussi les activités de collage des pneus devant sa boutique auprès des Services de Douanes de Sikasso, avec une clientèle composée généralement des propriétaires ou chauffeurs des véhicules gros porteurs avec lesquels il est beaucoup sollicité pour la qualité de ses marchandises et son travail. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à un premier prêt qui lui permettra d’acheter à Bobo et à Koumassi (respectivement au Burkina Faso et au Ghana) 10 pneus, 20 chambre à air, 15 jantes, etc.
 Ainsi, Il envisage réaliser avec ce premier crédit un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement  de contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Karim K. is 39 years old, married and the father of five children. He lives with his family in Bankoni, one of the outlying districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having operated several businesses without success, around 10 years ago Mr. K. began selling used items, such as tires, wheel rims, etc. He also runs a tire mounting business in front of his shop next to the Sikasso Customs Office. His clientele generally consists of business owners or drivers of large trucks. He is much in demand for the quality of his merchandise and his work. To satisfy increasing customer demand, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, where he has a first loan. This loan will enable him to buy 10 tires, 20 inner tubes, 15 wheel rims, etc. With this first loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 150,000 CFA which will be used principally to contribute to the family’s expenses and pay the interest on his loan, with the remainder to be invested in his business.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used tires, wheel rims and inner tubes

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Mariam T. N. est âgée de 46 ans, mariée et mère 7 enfants résidant avec son époux et leurs enfants à Médine, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Mariam T. N., après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée aux activités d’achat et de vente d’habillements, de pagnes wax, de chaussures, de tissus brodés, de draps de lit, de cache mur, etc depuis plus de dix ans. 
Elle achète ses marchandises à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre de façon ambulantes à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes de ménages. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de collaborer avec  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de six ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires dans une association des femmes de leur quartiers, elle est à son neuvième prêt individuel. Tous ses prêts précedents ont été correctement remboursés.
Ce  nouveau prêt lui permettra d’acheter, 5 complets de Cache-mur, 5 pièces de pagne wax, 3 complets de tissus brodés et 10 draps, etc.
 Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mariam T. N. is 46 years old, married and the mother of seven children. She lives with her husband ainc children in Médine, a working-class district of the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali) After having tried many activities without success, Ten years ago Mrs. Mariam T. N., launched a business selling clothing, wax “pagnes” [traditional colorful fabric], shoes, embroidered cloth, bed linens, wall coverings, etc. She purchases her wares in Bobo Dioulasso (in Burkina Faso) and resells them as a street vendor to a customer base composed manly of housewives. She is much appreciated by her customers due to high quality of her products. In order to meet the growing customer demand, more than six years ago she has decided to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yirwaso. After several solidarity loans under the aegis of the local women’s association, she is now on her ninth individual loan. All prior loans have been duly repaid. This new loan will allow her to purchase five sets of wall coverings, five sets of traditional wax “pagne” fabric, three sets of embroidered cloth, ten blankets etc. With this loan, she anticipates earning a monthly income of 90,000 West African Francs, which will be used to bolster her business capital, contribute to family expenses and pay off the interest on her loan.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing traditional wax pagnes fabric,  shoes, embroidered cloth, linens etc.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is 49 years old and married to Emelian, 67 years old - a farmer. They have two children, age 32 and 30 respectively. The family sources of income are farming and selling “taho” a vitamin-rich snack. It is a delicious snack with the following ingredients: processed soy beans, jelly and syrup. The family prepares and sells it to the community and in other localities. 

Erlinda is a member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. a partner micro-finance institution of KIVA in the Philippines since 2000. She’s been a very dedicated and active member of the institution. She joined ASHI to have access to capital to develop their food production business. She is applying for another loan of Php 25,000 to finance this business. The demand for their products starting this month is high that is why she needs more capital to buy raw materials for the production and additional aluminum basins for their vendors to use. Her dream is to construct an appropriate preparation area and increase their production. She believes that her business can also provide employment in their community and not just sustain their family needs.  She hopes that ASHI and KIVA will support her in these aspirations.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as soy beans, sugar, jelly and aluminum basins

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew is an active member and treasurer of Nkumari Group which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. He has been farming for the past 6 years and has employed 2 casual labourers. His main products are bananas and milk which he sells through middlemen and through the Imenti Dairy Society respectively. He also earns income from his commercial buildings at a local market and rental houses.

Andrew fully repaid his previous loan from Juhudi and has requested this loan of 50,000 KES to construct a zero-grazing shed. He says that the income from his farming will help pay college fees for one of his children. His primary challenges are high prices for dairy feed, high cost of labour, and insufficient water for irrigation.

In future, he intends to replace his current dairy cows with high yielding dairy cows and expand his banana plantation from the current 2 acres to 3 acres. He is happy with the services he has been getting from Juhudi. He says that Juhudi is the true financier of farmers.

Andrew is 62 years old. He is married with 7 children who are all adults.

loans.use: To constuct a zero-grazing shed

loans.name: Busheregyenyi Bakyara Kwebeishaho, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
M. Bennon of Busheregyenyi Bakyara Kwebeishaho group in Bushenyi is a fledgling agro-sales business trend setter whose example is bound to stand out as a benchmark for other people in his home area of Karehe Bushenyi. He has earned his living with a produce-sales business over a time frame of more than 4 years. 

Many in his home area occupy themselves with self-destructive activities like drinking alcohol and smoking marijuana rather than working hard and shouldering their family responsibilities. With his hard work ethic, M. Bennon has managed to prosper and in a month he apparently makes 200,000 Ugandan shillings. With his monthly savings, he has managed to diversify his small business where he is involved in coffee, beans and bananas sales.

This has however not come the easy way as he has had to grapple with many adversities such as unpredictable weather patterns which may mean he has fewer supplies from farmers. He is looking forward to purchasing more beans and coffee to stock for resale. With this loan he hopes to be in a position to cater for his children’s education costs as he looks forward to improving his household income.

loans.use: purchase more stock for resale

loans.name: 050303-Hai Long-Hoang Phong Group

texts.en:
Xuyen T. T. (8) is a 51-year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Hoa.  Xuyen is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 050303-Hai long-Hoang Phong (050303-Hai long-Hoang phong).

Xuyen is married and has 4 adult children.  To make a living, Xuyen operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for saL..  Xuyen has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Xuyen joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Xuyen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,626,900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The will be the 5th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Xuyen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. T. Vinh (15) is a 50-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


2.  L. T. Anh (18) is a 31-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


3.  L. T. Doan (16) is a 37-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her  fishing business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Xuyen T. T. (8) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang Hoa.  Xuyen là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 050303-Hai long-Hoang phong (050303-Hai long-Hoang phong).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  Xuyen thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 30 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Xuyen kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND.  Vào 2005, Xuyen đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Xuyen đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1,626,900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua con giống.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Vinh (15) là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


2.  L. T. Anh (18) là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  L. T. Doan (16) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: 050401 Phong My-Hoang Phong Group

texts.en:
Quyet L. T. (1) is a 48-year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Hoa.  Quyet is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 050401 Phong My-Hoang Phong (050401 phong my-Hoang phong).

Quyet is married and has three school-aged children.  To make a living, Quyet operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for saL..  Quyet has been engaged in this business for over 25 years and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Quyet joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Quyet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 5th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Quyet plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  L. T. Huong (10) is a 40-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  L. T. Yen (9) is a 40-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


3.  L. T. Hieu (3) is a 51-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


4.  C. T. Thuy (2) is a 31-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND.

1.  L. T. Huong (10) là 40 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  L. T. Yen (9) là 40 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  L. T. Hieu (3) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.
