loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members.    Jennifer has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 4 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Jennifer sells from home, wholesale and retail.    

Jennifer has requested a loan of 550,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.  The main business challenges for Jennifer include transportation and the rainy season which makes roads impassable.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to selling wholesale only.  

Jennifer lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara S. lives in Sevan with her son, daughter-in-law, and granddaughter. Tamara worked in a laundry for about 16 years. In 2006 she opened her own food shop and her son helps her a lot in her occupation. 

Thanks to her first Kiva loan, Tamara has organized household goods trading in her shop, which allowed her to increase her income from business and improved her family’s living conditions. 

Tamara purchases the merchandise for her shop from suppliers, but now she wants to receive 1.000.000 AMD loan to buy a car, which will allow her to purchase the merchandise for her shop from Yerevan and so to reduce the costs of her business.

loans.use: To buy a car for her business

loans.name: Jesus Is Real Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Jesus is Real” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 for each  to enable them to further develop their businesses. 

The leader of this group is Teresa K.. Teresa is age forty-eight; she was born in Bo, a city in southern Sierra Leone, but currently, she is residing in Makeni, together with her husband and five children. Her husband is a soldier and two of her children are attending primary school and secondary school respectively. Teresa has been selling smoked fish for many years now and with her share of this loan, she will buy smoked fish wholesale to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy smoked fish wholesale to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr: kossiwa est une revendeuse de produits d'alimentation générale, elle fait son commerce il y a 4 ans déjà. elle exerce son commerce dans son quartier de gblinkomé en dressant un étalage à la devanture de sa maison. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes. son stock de marchandises est en baisse, elle souhaite se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 5 bidons d'huile, 10 cartons de savons, 5 sacs de riz parfumés, 50 bols de maïs et divers. elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants.
texts.en:
Kossiwa sells food products. She sells in her district of Gblinkomé, setting up a stand in frond of her house. Her customer base is very diverse. Since her stock is getting low, she would like to replenish it, which is why she is seeking a loan from WAGES in order to purchase 5 cans of oil, 10 cartons of soap, 5 bags of flavored rice, 50 bowls of corn and other miscellaneous utens. She is married and the mother of three children.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing food products

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr: essi est une femme très dynamique, elle est célibataire et pour subvenir à ses besoins, elle a entamé en 2002, le commerce d'oignons, elle tient le monopole de ce commerce dans son quartier car elle est la seule à vendre de l'oignon, sa clientèle est pour la majorité constituée de gens de son quartier. son stock s'épuise, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 5 sacs d'oignons. elle s'approvisionne au burkina faso et au niger.
texts.en:
Essi is a very energetic woman. She is single and in order to provide for her needs, she started selling onions in 2002. She holds the monopoly of this business in her neighborhood, as she is the only one to sell onions. Her customer base is mainly composed of people living in her neighborhood. Her supply is running out and she would like to stock up. She is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 5 sacks of onions. She gets her supplies from Burkina Faso and Niger.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase onions

loans.name: Tarmarsu Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT) is very pleased to present to you members of the “Tarmarsu” group from Makeni. They are small-scale businesswomen who are based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mary K.. Mary is age thirty-five and was born in a place called Sanda near Makeni city. She is married to a businessman and they have two children – one in primary school and one in secondary school. 

Mary sells cooked rice (the country’s staple food) and foo-foo (food made out of cassava roots). She has been running this business for ten years now. She will use her share of this loan to buy cooking materials like rice, groundnuts, palm oil, tomatoes, etc.

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy cooking materials like rice, groundnuts, palm oil, tomatoes, etc.

loans.name: United Youth, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel T. is a member of the United Youth Group, Bushenyi.  He is hard-working, married, the father of seven children, and has had a goat farm business for over seven years in Rwenyana, Bushenyi.  He says he began this business when friends encouraged him to join them in the goat selling business.

His customers make him a profit of 60,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.  He is currently faced with the big challenge of having small stock in the business.  His motive to get this loan is to lend a hand in the purchasing of more stock for his business to improve sales revenue.  This will enable him to get income to buy family assets and live a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase goats for resale.

loans.name: Battulga

texts.en:
Battulga Z. is 47 years old, a married man with four children. He and his family live in a house in Uvs province of Mongolia. His older two children attend university while his younger two children study at a local high school. Battulga worked as a driver in a power station from 1990 to 2005 while his wife operated a fats and intestine trading business alone. He started to help his family's business in 2005 by purchasing large amounts of livestock intestines and sorting its fats for sale. 

Fats are very popular products, especially in the countryside. His business has grown quickly over the years and he has gained much experience as a businessman. His earnings have enabled him to pay his children's tuition fees as well as to decorate his house. 

For the future, he hopes to purchase a new car for his business. Battulga is a very gentle and polite person and says " I have been working very hard for the past several years and was able to improve my family's standard of living. Now I am planning to save my earnings in order to purchase a new car." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of fats and intestines for future sale.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of fats and intestines

loans.name: Magamaga Development Group-Jinja

texts.en: I. Cristopher has been partial to hard work ever since he began his retail shop business 10 years ago in Magamaga-Jinja. Cristopher, who belongs to the Magamaga Development Group, is 40 years old and happily married with 6 kids who all attend school, thanks in part to his dedication in paying for their education. He started this business after he dropped out of school. In a week, he makes profits that add up to 100,000 shillings and with this loan he is looking at buying more retail goods for his shop. He is looking at buying more bags of sugar, bars of soap, rice, maize flour and plastics for resale.

loans.use: The purchase of more bags of sugar, bars of soap, rice, maize flour and plastics for resale

loans.name: God Dae Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “God Dae” group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 for each in the group. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, making more sales and better profit. 

Mariama K. is the leader of this group. Mariama was born in Makeni. She is twenty-nine years of age, married to a soldier, and they have two children who are attending primary school. Mariama sells slippers and clothes. She has been doing this business for five years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy slippers and clothes in large quantity to add to her business.

loans.use: Buy slippers and clothes in large quantity to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Moussa S. est homme marié de 37 ans et père d’un enfant. Il vit avec sa femme et son enfant dans le quartier Torakabougou de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Moussa S. a abandonné l’école  très tôt pour tenter pendant des années, différentes activités génératrices de revenus qui n’ont pas été couronnées de succès en raison surtout de la faiblesse de son fonds de roulement.
Finalement Moussa en plus de ses activités de prestations de pulvérisation de cours et jardins, il appris auprès d’un de ses amis, la vente de carburant.
Avec une expérience de plus de 10 ans, il maîtrise son activité.
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle, il décide d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, pour acheter, 5 bidons de 20 litre du gaz-oil et  des produits pour la pulvérisation.
Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni. Il est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Son atelier est situé au bord la route reliant Bougouni à Sikasso.
Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 45 000FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour améliorer son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Moussa S. is a 37-year-old married man and father of one child. He lives with his wife and his child in the neighborhood of Torakabougou in Bougouni (Third administrative region of Mali). Mr. Moussa S. stopped going to school early on and tried for years various income-generating activities. These were not successful mostly because of his lack of working capital. Eventually Moussa learned the sale of fuel from his friends. This is in addition to his services of spraying courtyards and gardens. He has a 10-year experience and masters his activity. In order to meet his clients' demand he decided to join the loan program from Soro Yiriwaso to buy five 20-liter drums of diesel fuel and products for spraying. He gets his supplies in Bougoni. This is his first experience with Soro Yiriwaso. His shop is located on the road from Bougoni to Sikasso. His customers are local people. He hopes to make a monthly profit of 45 000 Francs CFA which will be used mostly to improve his business.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Héléna

texts.fr: Y. est une femme âgée et dynamique, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de bouillie faite à base de farine de blé accompagné de galette et elle vend également du jus, elle travaille les matins et les soirs car les matins les gens consomment de la bouillie pour le petit déjeuner. elle voudrait s'approvisionner pour dynamiser son activité raison pour laquelle elle sollicite du crédit pour l'achat de  2 sacs de farine de blé, 2 sacs de sucre, 4 bidons d'huile et un congélateur. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes.
texts.en:
Héléna is an energetic elderly woman. In order to earn a living, she sells "bouillie" (a type of porridge) made from wheat flour along with "galette" (a sort of pancake). She also sells juice. She works mornings and evenings because people eat porridge in the morning for breakfast. She would like to stock up to boost her business. As a result, she is requesting a loan to buy 2 sacks of wheat flour, 2 sacks of sugar, 4 cans of oil and a freezer. Her customer base is made up of all types of people.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Blue Arrow Group-Jinja

texts.en:
To illustrate his success in his business, 35-year-old K. Moses of Blue Arrow Group in Jinja, Uganda, feels he needs to emphasize his hard work over the course of the last seven years in his tender contract service work. His work revolves mostly around the collection of revenue from restaurant owners and taxi operators.

The hardworking Moses says he was formerly employed at a local factory. This, he says, gave him some firsthand experience on how to run a business. The happily married father of two says he makes 54,000 UGX in weekly profits. Moses says that he does not waste the money he earns but uses it for his family especially in times of necessity such as for school fees. With this loan he will pay off his debts to the local council administration. He is grateful that he is a part of his group.

loans.use: To cancel debts to the local council administration

loans.name: Kiribedda Group-Mpigi

texts.en:
28-year-old Henry W. who belongs to Kiribedda Group in Mpigi, Uganda, is honest when he gives credit to his close friend who he says prevailed upon him to start his current shoe sales business. Since then he has done all he can not to fall short of his envisioned goals. With a determined and unwavering attitude Henry has succeeded in making profitable use of his time at the helm of this business. This single father of one says he makes 50,000 UGX weekly.

With this loan he wants to buy more pairs of new shoes to sell. He is also looking at starting a brick-making business. Henry says that he had a retail shop before turning to shoe sales and does not regret his move.

loans.use: To purchase new pairs of shoes to sell

loans.name: Manzura Kazybekova's Group

texts.en:
Sometimes life is not as would be normally expected. Even a highly educated person must have a good sense of luck. In Kyrgyzstan, especially in villages, people have learned to work hard. Most often this work is manual labor. But as is known, any kind of labor is good.

Manzura K. is the leader of this group. She is 31, married and has two young children who go to the nursery school “Ak Kaiyn.” Her husband is a crane operator. Manzura is a first category specialist in sports and works in the House of Culture. In past years she did house repairs. Manzura also breeds livestock to sell. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase two sheep for breeding. In the near future the family wants to buy a Volkswagen.

Nargiza D. is the treasurer of this group. She is 25, married and is temporarily bringing up her daughter by herself because her husband is working in Russia. By leaving the child in a kindergarten, she has had more time to work at her business of breeding cattle. She has been doing so successfully for four years, yet the family can’t afford major purchases. She needs a loan in order to buy two goats for breeding. Nargiza still cherishes the hope of buying a new house with modern conveniences.

Almazbek S., 25, is a bachelor. He raises money by breeding cattle. Presently he has one cow and eleven goats. He would like a loan to buy two more goats for breeding. Almazbek is planning to marry in the near future.

Eliza D., 22, is married to a private builder. The couple has two small daughters. This young wife raises money by breeding cattle. As a result of hard work, she has three head of livestock. Eliza needs a loan to buy two goats for breeding. She wishes to obtain a car for herself.

About Mol Bulak Finance:

This loan is being presented by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of its “3-Ps” concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow larger) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Kizinda Matookye, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
It is now six years since Zahara K. of Kizinda Matookye group, Bushenyi, started up her banana-selling business in Kizinda, Bushenyi in western Uganda. With this as her only source of livelihood, she has painstakingly managed to make ends meet while contending with some seasonal income fluctuations and poor road systems to access bigger markets. With a strong work ethic, this 40-year-old married and happy-go-lucky mother of four children has kept her business growing, earning about 100,000 Ugandan shillings each month.

As her business has grown over the years, Zahara's family's living conditions have improved, and her business plan is to be able to sell more bananas to an expanding market as she looks at buying a vehicle for transportation. With this loan, she plans to purchase more bananas from the agriculturalists in the area for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas for resale

loans.name: Ola

texts.en:
Ola is a mother and housewife from Gaza Strip. Ola is a mother of three daughters: Lina, Lana and Farah. Her husband, Yousef, is a Palestinian National Authority employee and runs a bookstore. The bookstore where Yousef appears in the picture is located in the schools' area.

Ola helps her husband manage the work at the bookstore when he is at work. As school is starting this week, Ola and Yousef needed a $1500 loan to purchase stationary and school new year preparations. Ola came to FATEN for the loan and was able to buy the needed goods for the new year.

The bookstore helps the family manage their expenses. Ola doesn't appear in the picture as she comes from a conservative background.

loans.use: To purchase stationary

loans.name: Jyparkan's Group

texts.en:
Work is an essential part of life for all human beings. Most people work to make their living so they can afford food, housing, and education for their children. People need some physical and mental exercise for healthy living. The essential fact is that your style of life depends on your work.

Jyparkan A., the leader of the group, is 34, married, and has one daughter. Eight years ago, in order to use an inheritance profitably, she started her own business. Since then, the family has worked hard with a well-deserved result: 4 cows, 8 sheep, and 35 goats. Jyparkan and her family now need a loan to clean a slaughter and prepare a coal supply for winter. Her most important goal is to increase the size of her cattle stock.

Mirgul B. is the treasurer of the group. Although a very young married woman, she already has two small daughters. The main family income derives from the supply and resale of coal. The loan's purpose is to buy a car.

Askat M., 24 and married to a school teacher, has a baby son. Askat makes his living by coal supplying and its further resale. Making plans for the future, he intends to expand his business.

Azamat K., a 24-year-old bachelor, raises money by coal supplying and its resale in a neighboring region. The loan's purpose is to buy more coal for resale in the winter when it is most in demand. Next year, Azamat is planning to obtain a new house and get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase coal for winter

loans.name: Kadirmat

texts.en:
Kadirmat M. is a 48-year-old farmer who lives in Ozgorush Village, in northwest Kyrgyzstan. He is married and has four children. Kadirmat worked as a driver but his salary didn’t cover all the expenses of his large family. That’s why Kadirmat decided to begin his business in animal breeding and land cultivation. As a very purposeful and positive person, Kadirmat has worked hard to support his family. The desire to support his family led him to obtain two loans from “Bai Tushum and Partners”, which were repaid without any delays. The revenue from these activities allowed him to purchase two cows and 15 sheep.

Now Kadirmat plans to use this loan of KGS 75,000 to buy five bull-calves for fattening and reselling. In the future, Kadirmat plans to provide higher education for his children. Also, Kadirmat wants to buy a minivan in order to help his elder son to start his own business in transportation.

Bai Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target especially vulnerable people. Bai Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Burulai's Group

texts.en:
According to the historical facts, Kyrgyzstan was known as the land of nomads. The main occupations of the Kyrgyz people were cattle breeding and farming. Since that time, many things have been changed. Now it is the country of contrasts: contrasts between richness and poverty. In the cities people work in modern offices, but in small villages people have to lead their ancestors’ mode of life.

Burulai K. is the leader of the group. She is 52, a widow. At the present moment she has a job as the cook in the Tashkumyr professional lycee (secondary school). Twenty years ago, by personal initiative, she bought three goats, and during the years she has managed to obtain a “Niva” car. Burulai wants to get a loan to buy more goats for breeding. One of the most important aims for Burulai is to buy a new car.

Abdipatta J., 42, together with his wife, who works as a cook, is raising four daughters. His business started five years ago with cattle breeding. Besides running his business, he works as an electrician in Jalalabat. During his working years has managed to buy a foreign car. The purpose of his loan is to create household buildings.

Talantbek O., 26, is married and has two infant children. Two years ago his wife’s parents incited him to start his own business by presenting him with a cow. Besides his business he has a current job as an electrician in Jalalabat. He has been making a profit, and has managed to buy necessary domestic appliances. The purpose of his loan is to buy livestock for further breeding. Talantbek is planning to buy a house with modern conveniences.

Sabirahan J., 61, is a widow. She earns her livelihood by working as a watchman in a professional lycee. Besides her job, she breeds cattle. Planning for the future, Sabirahan wants to build a bath-house, garage and other necessary outbuildings.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase goats for breeding

loans.name: Maira's Group

texts.en:
Sooner or later almost every one of us begins to think of further life plans. Every individual has his or her own. Education, family, job, hobby — the most common plans of a human being. No matter what country you live in, what race or nationality you belong to, what kind of hobby you like to spend your free time with, you want to live a worthy life. Unfortunately, unstable political and economical situations are not the best circumstances in which to build a worthwhile life. Nevertheless, people by their very nature are trying to improve their way of life.

Maira K. has the status of group leader. She is 58, married, and has two adult daughters. Her husband’s profession is hard, but not so well-paid; he is a teacher. He is already on a pension, but still has to support his family. The purpose of this loan is to buy building material for major repairs to the house. In order to repay the loan, Maira’s husband will use his pension money and his salary. In the future, both parents want to give their daughters in marriage to good men and organize both of their weddings.

Maira’s partners:

Azada A. is 69. She is married and has a rather big family. The family (husband, son, daughter-in-law and grandchildren) live together. Azada is a retiree. The purpose of her loan is to buy building materials to make thorough repairs to the house. Their intentions for the future are to do the house repairs and increase the number of cattle they own.

Dinara I. is 27, married, and raising two toddlers. A year ago she began her business of foodstuff retail selling. The purpose of her loan is to increase the range of foodstuffs she offers for sale. In the future, Dinara is planning to buy a new house.

Burabiya A., 50, is married. She is the treasurer of the group. She has four children, two of which are students. She makes her living by sewing coverlets and items for dowries on order for local people. She began her business with a national sewing manufacturer. The purpose of her loan is to buy more materials for sewing. In the future Burabiya intends to organize her children’s weddings.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase building materials

loans.name: Abd Al Hadi

texts.en: Abd Al Hadi is a 30-year-old married man living in Chtoura with his wife and two children. Abd Al Hadi has been working as a van driver since 2000; it’s his only source of income. He works hard on changing his family’s financial and social situation, through working on weekends and by taking groups for outings and trips all over Lebanon. Abd Al Hadi is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy a school bus to increase his income. Now that it is school season and he needs to catch it from the beginning. Abd Al Hadi transports employees from their homes to work and the opposite. He is committed to those employees and they trust him a lot. His good reputation is his work’s foundation, and that is why people support him so much.

loans.use: To buy a school bus

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah N. lives in the Makerere neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has three children, all of whom have finished school. She also takes care of additional family members (orphans). Deborah has a business selling secondhand clothes. She has been operating this business on retail and moves door to door selling her clothes. Deborah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bales of clothes. She generates additional income through working as a health worker with MAWDA (Makerere Women’s Development Association).
The main business challenges for Deborah include the rainy season, transportation, and debtors. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to build rental rooms and start importing clothes herself. She decided to work with MCDT because of the low interest rate and getting timely loans. Deborah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees for the orphans, medication, and food.

loans.use: To buy more bales of clothes

loans.name: Burul Apsamatova's Group

texts.en:
People always want to experience something new, to discover the world, to uncover secrets.  Humanity is always anxious for success. Even in developing countries where in order to achieve, one should make every effort, people hope for the best. 

Burul A. is 55, a widow and is leader of the group. Now her children are most important in supporting her. Her daughter is a saleswoman in a sausage shop, while her daughter-in-law helps her to run a business. Seventeen years ago Burul began to earn money by sewing small orders for fellow villagers. She has finally seen some personal results from her efforts: she managed to buy a new electric sewing machine with the help of which she will sew national cloth and dressmaking supplies. With a loan Burul wants to buy a multi-logic sewing machine. Burul’s aim is to open sewing workshop.

Gulmira A. is the group treasurer. She is 41, married and has three children. Her husband is a guest worker in Russia. Besides selling towels in the market, she gets some material support from her older children. With a loan she would like to increase her commodity’s circulation and to buy more towels to sell. In the future Gulmira is planning to open her own private shop. 

Daniyar M., 27, is married and has two infants. Six years ago he decided to start a private enterprise in Taras, Kazakhstan, breeding cattle. Now he is working in the wholesale and retail towel trade. His loan purpose is to increase his working capital.

Aiymkan A., 36, is marriedand runs her business by herself because her husband is working in Russia. She makes a profit from sewing items by request. In the past she was a saleswoman of children’s clothes in Bishkek. She has managed to buy an auto and some cattle. The purpose of her loan is to buy more material for sewing. Aiymkan wishes to see her dream of building a new house come true.

About Mol Bulak Finance:

This loan is being presented by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of its “3-Ps” concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow larger) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Abd Al Rahman

texts.en:
Abd A. Rahman is a 52-year-old married man living in Chtoura with his wife and three children. Abd A. Rahman works in multiple jobs depending on the village’s needs. His major business is blacksmithing. He's still working at this trade, but to provide a good living for his family, he has had to search for more than one source of income. During the summer, he sells water in Chtoura and the neighboring villages because unfortunately Lebanon is always in need of water during this season. In the winter, Abd A. Rahman sells firewood to villagers so that they might stay warm.

Abd A. Rahman is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to buy tools necessary to his work. He hopes to expand and develop his work in the future.

loans.use: To buy tools necessary to his work

loans.name: Karukara Women's A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Hard-working Annah M. of Karukara Women's Group, Kihihi, Uganda, has been running a retail shop from Omukabingo trading centre in Kihihi, where she sells general merchandise for home use. She has been operating this business for over seven years now. She started this business with capital she got from selling a local brew known as “waragi.” The married mother of four children confirms that her store’s stock is not satisfying her customers’ demands.

Therefore Annah is seeking a loan to help her buy more goods for resale. She hopes earn more income, thus being in a position to help with her family needs and standard of living. She belongs to a group of other members who hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her shop

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.en:
K. Jamshed is 31 years old. He is married with 4 children. Jamshed has a small restaurant where he sells breakfast, lunch and dinner. Prior to opening his own business, he worked at a restaurant where he learned the ins and outs of the trade. 

When Jamshed first started his business, he only opened to sell breakfast because he worked at night. Once his place became more popular, he was able to dedicate his whole time to the business. 

Jamshed wants the loan so he may invest in tables, chairs and utensils. He is asking for a loan of 3000 USD. With this money, Jamshed will be able to expand his business, to earn more profit and in turn help his children move forward to complete their school studies and further continue studying at the university. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing tables, chairs and utensils to expand his cafe business

loans.name: Abduhalim

texts.en:
M. Abduhalim is 31 years old, married and has three children. He is a farmer growing onions, corn, rice, and nuts--something he has done for 11 years. This is the only thing he knows how to do and what he likes most to do. For Abduhalim, there is nothing better than being in touch with nature and watching the crops he has planted grow year after year.

 In addition, Abduhalim raises cattle and his family helps him with his business. Now he wants to borrow money to purchase seeds and fertilizer for his crops. This is the second loan of Abduhalim from IMON International and he promises to repay the loan without any violations as he did with his previous loan.

These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret N. lives in the Kisaasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has  six children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members.    

Margaret has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Margaret sells from home, retail.    Margaret has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.The main business challenges for Margaret include transportation and the rainy season which makes roads impassable.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only.   Margaret lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua D. is married and takes care of four children. Her husband is a petty trader. She has not acquired any formal education. Efua sells 'kenkey' (a fermented maize staple food) at Elmina. Efua uses her income to help her husband in the payment to school fees and utility bills.  She will use the loan to purchase more maize to prepare 'kenkey' for distibution. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to save to invest in the sale of other cereals.

loans.use: purchase more maize to prepare 'kenkey' for distibution

loans.name: Karukara Women's B, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
K. Jolly of Karukara Women's group, Kihihi, aged 51 years, is a married mother of 7 children. She has been operating a retail shop from Kagongi trading centre, Kihihi, selling general merchandise for over 8 years. This is the business she started after leaving her previous farming enterprise.

She trades in a variety of products for domestic use like sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil, paraffin and much more earning her 120,000 Ugandan shillings weekly. 

Her main drawback is that she has limited stock of products in her shop that cannot satisfy the customers' demand. Therefore Jolly is looking forward to increasing the stock in her business when she gets this loan and also expands into a wholesale shop. This will help her earn more revenue and sustain her daily needs as she envisions improving her family’s standard of living and further educating her children.

All group members hold one another accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: purchase more stock for her general store

loans.name: Burulkan

texts.en:
Burulkan A. is a 54-year-old farmer, who lives in Belovodskoe village. She was born into a low-income family with eleven children and was the main helper of her parents in the household: she looked after the younger children, pastured  cattle, and milked cows. 

When she was 20, she was given in marriage and gave a birth to her two sons.  At that time Burulkan’s  family had only one milch cow. Later, their livestock grew and they got one more milch cow and two bull-calves. In 1996, Burulkan gave a birth to her beloved daughter, who today lives with her. 

During all these years, Burulkan aimed her efforts at supporting and expanding their household. In 2005, she had to sell a part of her cattle to hold her son’s marriage.

Now Burulkan requests a loan of 30,000 KGS to buy bull-calves and pigs for fattening and reselling. That will allow her to further develop the business. In the future, Burulkan wants to construct a barn for her cattle and dreams of buying a car for the family some day. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population.  Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase calves and piglets

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah N. lives in the Kamwokya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school.  Deborah has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Deborah sells her products at the market, wholesale.   

 Deborah has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more sacks of charcoal.   She also generates additional income through rental rooms. The main business challenges for Deborah include seasonality and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to see her business grow and start going directly to producers.   Deborah lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama O. is divorced and takes care of six dependents. She has been through senior high school.  Ama operates a 'fufu' and 'Twozaafi' (thick corn porridge) T.z. joint at Elmina. Ama uses her income in feeding, clothing and educating her dependents.  Ama will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to cook for sale. With the new revenue from her expanded business, Ama plans on ploughing her profit back into the business.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to cook for sale

loans.name: David Weru

texts.en:
David Weru N. is 42 years old and he supports a family of three. He is married and he has two school-going children, aged twelve and nine. David is a businessman running an electronics shop in Narok town. He has been in this business for the last five years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is already a registered member in KADET. This will be his second loan which he is planning to use to buy more electronics goods to increase his stock. He hopes to use the anticipated profit from this loan to expand his business and open up another electronics shop in another street within Narok town.

David’s dream is to become a wholesaler and be the electronic goods distributor in Narok town. He is a hardworking man with great vision.

loans.use: To buy more elecronic goods to increase his stock

loans.name: Nick Parsokonte

texts.en:
Nick Parsokonte P. is 27 years old. He is married to Mugeso P. and he is a father of two children. Nick is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last five years.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend the thirty thousand to prepare land for planting wheat which has proved to be doing very well due to favorable climatic conditions. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to plough a bigger piece of land for farming to increase his wheat production. 

His future dream is that he will become a large-scale wheat farmer in his area. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to prepare land for planting wheat

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena D. is married and has one child. She has received junior high school education. Abena sells cooked rice with tomato sauce in Elmina. She has been in this business for five years. Her husband is a trader. Abena uses her income to help her husband supply the basic needs of the family. Abena will use this loan to purchase more rice and other ingredients to cook for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Abena plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more rice and other ingredients to cook for sale

loans.name: Anne Emelia

texts.en: Anne Emelia N. sells cassava, plantain and other foodstuffs in Elmina. She is married and has one child. Anne has not acquired any form of education. She responsibly supports her husband with the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more of her foodstuffs to sell. She anticipates using the new earnings from her business to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married to an engineer. They have four children, and all of them are at school. Her greatest expenses are school fees and food.

Margaret has been selling bananas for 16 years. She sells them seven days a week to local people at the market. Margaret buys bunches of bananas from delivery vans that get them from villages. Her main challenge is seasonality.

Margaret joined MCDT to get additional capital for her banana business. She plans to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She aspires to go directly to the villages to buy her bananas herself.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica B. is married to a trader and takes care of two children. She sells rice and tomato sauce in Elmina. She has been educated up to the senior high school level. Veronica uses her income to help her husband pay for their accommodation. Veronica will use this loan to purchase a bag of rice and other ingredients to cook for sale. Veronica plans to save the new profits from her expanded business to build a shop.

loans.use: To purchase a bag of rice and other ingredients to cook for sale

loans.name: Kanyike Murdoi

texts.en:
Kanyinke Murdoi K. is 41 years old and has grown wheat for the last ten years. He is married to Tialo Ene Murdoi. They have four children aged between six and sixteen years. Tialo is a housewife and she helps Kanyinke in his farming.

This will be Kanyinke’s first loan. He is planning to spend 35,000 KES on chemicals and fertilizer, and 15,000 KES to spray his wheat field. He is planning to use the anticipated profit from his farming to rent a bigger piece of land so as to increase his wheat production. He hopes and dreams that he will become a large-scale farmer owning a bigger piece of land and so be financially stable enough to support his family.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and fertilizer and to spray his wheat field

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana N. is married and has three children. She has no formal education. Diana sells charcoal and foodstuffs in Elmina. Diana uses her income to feed her family as a way of helping her husband. She will use this loan to purchase more charcoal and food supplies to sell. Diana has plans of reinvesting the new profits from her expanded business back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and food supplies for sale

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba T. sells cloth and fried fish in Elmina. She has received junior high school education. She is divorced and lives with her four children. Her ex-husband is a trader. She is responsible for the general welfare of her home. Her loan will be used to buy additional fresh fish to fry to distribute to her customers. She hopes to save the new profits from her business to revive her cloth business.

loans.use: To buy additional fresh fish to fry to distribute to her customers

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama A. is a married woman with a child. She is into the sale of ladies shoes and lining materials in Elmina. She sells by moving from one area to another. She has been through junior high school. Ama uses her income to help her husband with the general upkeep of the home. Ama will use this loan to purchase more ladies shoes and lining materials for sale. Ama plans on reinvesting the new profits from her expanded business back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase extra goods for sale

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
31-year-old Charles W. is married and has six children. For the last five years he has relied on his tenacious and strong-willed manner of conduct to establish a good reputation for himself in his teaching job. With this reputation he has been able to make all sorts of strides in terms of getting invitations to teach in many other schools around Nakakandwa Subcounty in Kayunga. In a week, he makes 210,000 UGX.

To supplement his remuneration as a teacher he also does some small-scale farming and animal husbandry. With this loan he wants to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Julius Komen

texts.en:
Julius K. C. is 33 years old. He is married to Edna Komen, and they are blessed with five children: Maximilien is 11 years old, Sharon is 9 years old, Faith is 7 years old, Denis is 4 years old, and Consolata is 3 years old.

To earn a living, Julius is a farmer, though he also runs a welding business. He explains that he has been operating the two businesses for the last 10 years and that the businesses generate for him an average profit of 10,000 KES per month. By doing so, Julius supports his family of 7 people.

Julius is seeking a loan in the amount of 42,000 KES ($525) from KADET LTD. This would be the second loan he has received from KADET LTD. Notably, he successfully repaid the first loan. He intends to use 10,000 KES of the requested loan to purchase fertilizers, 7,000 KES to purchase maize seeds, 15,000 KES for tilling, and the remaining 10,000 KES to purchase metals for his welding business. Julius hopes to use the profits generated from his businesses as a result of this loan to build rental houses in the town of Kabarnet. Ultimately, he dreams of expanding his business and of being able to educate his children to the highest level of education possible.

loans.use: To expand his businesses by purchasing farming and welding products

loans.name: Mercy Ekua

texts.en: Mercy Ekua N. is married and has two children. She has received junior high school education. Mercy Ekua sells raw maize and rice in both small and large quantities in Elmina. Her husband is a trader. Mercy Ekua uses her income to assist her husband with the payment of school fees and utility bills. Mercy Ekua will use this loan to purchase more of her goods for sale. Mercy Ekua plans to save the new profits from her expanded business to build a storehouse for her goods.

loans.use: To purchase more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Seleto Ene

texts.en:
Seleton Ene S. is 25 years old, and she supports two members of her family. She explains that she is a hard working woman who is determined to achieve her goals.

To earn a living, Seleton is a farmer. Specifically, she farms on her own piece of land, and she has been doing so for the last four years.

She learned about KADET LTD from other women who are already registered members of KADET LTD in her area of residence. She is seeking a loan in the amount of 25,000 KES ($325), which would be her first loan from KADET LTD. With the loan proceeds, she would like to buy pestsides to spray her crops (mostly wheat) to prevent them from being invaded by pests. She hopes to use the profits generated from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activities from small-scale to commercial-level farming. In fact, Seleton's dream is run a large-scale farming operation and to attain financial independence.

loans.use: to spend twenty five thousands buy pestsides

loans.name: Eudelina

texts.es:
La Sra. Eudelina C. de 43 años de edad, es casada, tiene una hija de 23 años de edad, ella se dedicaba a la venta de ropas de forma ambulante, después de muchos años y con mucho esfuerzo pudo comprar una casilla detrás mismo del Centro de Salud de Cnel. Oviedo.
Con la ayuda de su hija ella elabora alimentos como empanadas, sandwich, milanesas, y le da de comer a pacientes, parientes y enfermeras del hospital, gracias a su esfuerzo y el empeño e higiene que pone a la hora de elaborar sus productos ella pudo formar su clientela que día  a dia se van a desayunar, almorzar y merendar en su puesto.
La Sra. Eudelina agradece a Kiva y a la Fundación Paraguaya por el apoyo brindado porque gracias a eso ella pudo comprar mas carne, fideos, arroz, lácteos, golosinas, gaseosas, etc. para seguir dando a sus clientes la mas rica comida y al mejor precio ,de esa forma ayudar a su marido con los gastos de la casa.
texts.en:
Eudelina C., age 43, is married and has a 23 year old daughter. She used to sell clothes in an itinerant manner. After many years, and with much effort, she was able to buy a stall behind the Colonel Oviedo Health Center. With her daughter’s help she makes food like empanadas, sandwiches, and breaded cutlets. She feeds patients, family members, and nurses at the hospital. Thanks to the effort and hard-work she puts into making her products and her good hygiene, she was able to get her customers. They come to her stall day to day to eat breakfast and lunch and to snack. Eudelina is grateful to Kiva and the Fundación Paraguaya for the support they have provided. Thanks to this support she was able to buy more meat, noodles, rice, dairy products, sweets, and soft drinks, etc. She bought these to continue giving her customers the most delicious food at the best price. This way she helps her husband with the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy meat, flour, eggs, sweets, and soft drinks, etc.

loans.name: Ayebi

texts.en: Ayebi A. sells slippers, shoes and provisions at Elmina. She has no formal education. She is married and living with five dependants. Ayebi has been in her trade for seven years. She responsibly supports her husband in the general upkeep of their home. Her loan will be used to purchase more provisions to fill her shop for sale. She hopes to reinvest in her business should there be any form of profit.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to fill her shop for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional bags of charcoal

loans.name: Gladys Kiserian

texts.en:
Gladys Kiserian S. is 32 years old, and she supports two members of her family. She explains that she is a hardworking woman who is determined to achieve her goals.

To earn a living, she is engaged in the wheat farming business. She has been in this line of work for the last 5 years, and she notes that she has been rather successful due to good weather conditions and a robust market for crops in her area.

She is now seeking her first loan in the amount of 30,000 KES ($375), which she plans to use to better prepare her land for wheat planting. She hopes to use the anticipated profits generated as a result of the loan to expand her wheat farming operation. Her dream is to become a large-scale farmer and to educate her kids so that are highly educated.

loans.use: To expand her business by preparing her land for wheat farming

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther T. is divorced and has five dependents. She has been through junior high school. Esther sells millet porridge and bread at Elmina. Her husband is a petty trader. Esther uses her income to pay her children’s school fees and family utility bills. Esther will use the loan to purchase more millet to prepare porridge. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esther plans to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: purchase more millet to prepare porridge.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. sells ladies', men's, and children’s slippers at Elmina. She has been in this business for five years now. Esi is married and has one child. She has not received any form of education. Esi uses her income to pay utiltiy bills as a way of helping her husband. Esi will use the loan to purchase more of her goods for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to save to further her child’s education.

loans.use: purchase more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa B. is married and has two children. She has received junior high education. Yaa prepares 'kooko' (porridge made from millet) and serves it with bread at Elmina. Her husband is a petty trader. 

Yaa uses her income to help her husband in providing the basic needs of the family. Yaa will use the loan to purchase additional ingredients to prepare 'kooko' for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Yaa plans to save to invest in her children’s education.

loans.use: purchase additional ingredients to prepare 'kooko' for sale.

loans.name: God Blessing #4 Group

texts.en:
Hawa K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of 5 borrowers known as "God Blessing #4." She is 41 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her children are between the ages of 9 and 23 years old. She explains that she was only able to attend school through the fitth grade due to financial constraints.

For the past 20 years, to earn a living, she has been selling red oil in the "Redlight Market” outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her portion (5,000 LRD) of the requested 25,000 LRD ($275) group loan to buy more gallons of red oil. She describes herself as an easy-going woman whose dream is to improve her business.

loans.use: To improve her business by purchasing additional red oil

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame T. sells fried doughnuts at Elmina. She is divorced and has three children. Her ex-husband is a petty trader. Maame has received junior high education. Maame uses her earnings to take care of her children. She hopes to use the loan to purchase more ingredients to prepare fried doughnuts for distribution. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans on reinvesting back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more ingredients to prepare fried doughnut

loans.name: Sunilda

texts.es:
La Sra. Sunilda V. D. I. tiene 43 años D. edad, esta casada con el Sr. Alvino I., tienen 2 hijos varones Emanuel y Sergio que están cursando la secundaria, y una nena llamada Mercedes que esta en el septimo grado.
Ella  es D. profesión  enfermera y comerciante. Tiene un negocio en su casa en el barrio Santa Lucia D. la ciudad D. Cnel. Oviedo.
Ella trabajó desD. muy joven como enfermera en un sanatorio privado D. la ciudad, y con el dinero que le dieron como indemnizacion al salir D. allí pudo habilitar una pequeña farmacia en su domicilio, D. a poco y con mucho esfuerzo comenzó a ganar clientela realizando toma D. presiones, aplicación D. inyecciones y primeros auxilios a  vecinos y amigos, con el correr D. los años y como su marido enfermo tuvieron que vender su auto taxi donD. trabajaba él e invirtió en su negocio, D. esa forma pudo ampliarlo, y actualmente lo maneja con su marido y sus hijos.
La Sra. Sunilda agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya y a Kiva por el apoyo y gracias a este crédito pudo comprar mas productos como fideos, galletitas, leches, yogurt, harina, arroz gaseosa, jarabes, inyectables,  geringas, analgesicos, pasta dental, golosinas, café, etc. para poder D. esa forma seguir brindando a su clientela productos D. primera necesidad y D. buena calidad.
texts.en:
Sunilda V. D. I., age 43, is married to Alvino I.. They have two sons, Emanuel and Sergio; they go to high school. They have a daughter, Mercedes, who is in seventh graD.. She is a nurse and a merchant. She has a business in her house in the Santa Lucia neighborhood in the city of Colonel Oviedo. When she was very young she worked as a nurse in a private sanitarium in the city. With the money they gave her as compensation when she left she was able to equip a small pharmacy in her home. A short while after, and with great effort, she began to win customers. She takes blood pressures and gives injections and first aid to her neighbors and friends. As the years passed and her husband became ill, they had to sell his taxi and invest in her business. This way she was able to expand her business. She currently manages it with her husband and their children. Sunilda is grateful to the Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for the support. Thanks to this loan she was able to buy more products like noodles, cookies, milk, yogurt, flour, rice, soft drinks, syrup, injectables, syringes, analgesics, tooth paste, sweets, and coffee, etc. She did this to be able to keep offering her customers good quality basic needs products.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy flour, meat, chicken, soft drinks, noodles, rice, sugar, dairy products, sweets, powdered soap, coffee, and toothpaste, etc.

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Mary C., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Is Able. She is 50 years old, married, and has seven children ages 14 to 33. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. 


For 30 years, she has been selling rice and palm oil in Red Light Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 5,000 LRD portion of this 25,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of rice and gallons of palm oil. She describes herself as a hard-working woman whose dream is to improve her business and continue her education.

loans.use: To buy more rice and palm oil

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 36 year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and five children. Hussein has owned a floor tile factory since 1999. Hussein wants to secure his family's way of living. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua so he can buy a generator to provide his factory with the necessary electricity, because electricity is a major problem in his region. This new machine will provide him with the necessary electricity, which will improve his work and increase his production. 

Hussein is ready for any additional business that can improve his living conditions. His clients are his neighbors, villagers, and neighboring villages.

loans.use: To buy a generator

loans.name: Reina

texts.es: La Sra. Reina Nacida en la ciudad de Santa Cruz, vive en el barrio el Bajio km 6 de la ciudad, su actividad principal es atención de una discoteca, también se dedica a la venta de producto de primera necesidad,  su esposo con el cual tienen dos hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar  es técnico de computadoras, el cual le ayuda en la economía del hogar, el destino del créditos es para comprar muebles para su negocio, ya que la discoteca de la Sra. Es muy conocida por la zona y tiene mucha clientela, es un apersona responsable y trabajadora, esta muy agradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Reina, from the city of Santa Cruz, lives in the barrio of Bajio, 6 kilometers from the city. Her principal activity is managing a discotheque and, also, she sells products of prime necessity. Her husband, with whom she has 2 children of school age, is a computer technician, and she helps him with household expenses. The loan will be used to buy furniture for her business, since the discotheque is well-known in the district and has a lot of clientèle. Reina is a responsible and hard-working person, and is very grateful to the institution for the offered help.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING FURNITURE FOR HER DISCOTHEQUE

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena E. sells fried doughnuts at Elmina. Abena has been educated up to the senior high level. She is married and has seven dependents. She has been in this business for quite some time now. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more ingredients to prepare doughnuts for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save up and begin baking bread.

loans.use: buy more ingredients to prepare doughnuts for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy rice, cassava, fish, meat, cooking oil, and so forth

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 30 year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and one child. Hussein has worked in construction since 2002. Hussein requested a loan from Al Majmoua because he wants to buy a crane for his work with concrete and a generator. His reputation helped in increasing his clients and income. Hussein seeks perfection in his work, and hopes to expand his construction work in the future

loans.use: To buy a crane and a generator

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mohamed J.

texts.en:
Mohamed is married to a trader and has two dependents.  He sells drinks and water at a stall in Makeni.  He is a jovial, kind, and very determined businessman.  Mohamed originally accessed funds from his elder brother. He has been in business for 11 years.  

Mohamed is in need of a loan of 3,000,000 SLL to buy additional stock for his stall.  He will use the proceeds of his loan to educate his children to the university level and to construct a house for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for his stall

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina is a 32-year-old married woman from Bint Jbeil. She is the mother of three children. Lina has owned an Internet shop (computer services) since 2009; this kind of business is becoming important in the region. Many teenagers seek such places to play network games with their friends and do necessary school research. 

Lina is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to buy extra computers for her shop. Her clients can be anyone in need of such a service. Lina hopes to expand her work in the future and start selling computer hardware.

loans.use: To buy extra computers

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, meat, cooking oil, tomatoes, salt, seasonings, etc.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is married to a trader, who is also an active partner in their business. He has four children. He sells drinks and articles in Makeni. Ibrahim has a reputation for being a very dedicated and honest businessman. Originally, he accessed funds from the sale of his agricultural produce and he has now been in this business for over five years.  

Ibrahim is in need of a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 Sierra Leone Leones to buy more articles and drinks. He intends to use the proceeds of his loan to educate his four children to university level and begin saving for his retirement.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, articles, etc., for his shop

loans.name: Fanta

texts.en: Fanta is married to a teacher and has one child.  She sells ready-made items and shoes in Makeni.  She is a jovial and very intelligent businesswoman. Originally, Fanta accessed funds to begin her shop from her husband and began trade on ready-made items, which she has now maintained for 4 years. She is in need of a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 SLL to buy additional ready-made items. Fanta intends to use the proceeds of her loan to educate her children to the university level and to save for her future retirement.

loans.use: To add more stock of ready-made items.

loans.name: Nerea Aoko

texts.en:
Nerea Aoko K. is a widow aged 55. Nerea is blessed with seven children: Lameck, 31; Abigael, 24; Thomas, 15; Robert, 29; Philip, 26; Catherine, 20; and Peril, 18. Nerea runs a second-hand clothes shop in Kabarnet municipal market, which she has been running for the last 20 years. Through this business she has been able to support her family, providing for their basic needs.

Nerea has borrowed a loan of 80,000 KES, of which she will use 44,000 KES to buy four bales of second-hand clothes, 31,000 KES to purchase new clothes and 5,000 KES for rent. From her business, she gets an average profit of 15,000 KES. From these profits, Nerea intends to pay school fees for her children as well as to expand the business.

This is her forth loan from KADET LTD and Nerea anticipates that the loan will boost her business as the festive season is nearing. Nerea dreams are to open a second-hand clothes wholesale business and to educate her children to the highest level possible.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of second-hand clothes, new clothes and to pay rent.

loans.name: Edwin Kipkorir

texts.en:
Edwin Kipkorir C. is 25 years and married to Judy Yatich. They have a child who is nine months old. They live in Chepkoilel, outside of Eldoret town. Edwin has a communication service bureau and phone repair shop where he earns his income. He has been in this business for the past three years with an income of 5,200 KES per month.

Edwin was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer and he is applying for his first loan of 30,000 KES with KADET LTD, with which he plans to purchase phone accessories and spares.

He hopes to open the same business in the nearby town like Iten, Kabarnet, to increase family income.

loans.use: To purchase phone accessories and spares.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used shoes.

loans.name: Kyankaranga Twimukye, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
T. Perezi of Kyankaranga Twimukye group of Bushenyi is a 34-year-old married father of 5 boisterous school children. To shoulder his responsibility of providing for them, he has been operating a consumable items retail shop in Katerera Trading centre, Bushenyi, over the course of the last 4 years.

His business has not been without setbacks; since the beginning, he has had to bear a myriad number of challenges, such as the lack of steady income inflows. However, his business has remained active because of his hard work and good customer relations. He attributes this in most part to the good working chord he has struck with his clientele.

In a month, Perezi says he makes more than 400,000 UGX, a figure he admits will make his business see the light of near future. He is therefore seeking a loan to lend countenance to his business so that he is able to restock his shop as he looks for substantial growth.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for the business.

loans.name: Hopeful Friends Group

texts.en:
Edward K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Hopeful Friends.  He is 40 years old, single, and has three children whose ages are between eight months and eleven years. He presently attends college. 


For 20 years, he has been selling petroleum products in “Wood camp community” on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more petroleum products to sell. 

He describes himself as a hard-working man whose goals are to improve his business and continue with his education.

loans.use: To buy more petroleum products to sell

loans.name: Kiponza Group

texts.en:
Sharifu A. is in his early thirties and is married with one three-year-old daughter. Sharifu owns a carpentry shop which he has been running for nine years. He works from 7 am to 6 pm daily and makes a monthly income of about $200.

This will be Sharifu’s third Motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A Motisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term ends. 

He used his first loan to buy cement and wood. He used his second loan to open a mobile phone shop where he sells and repairs mobile phones. He wants to use his third loan on a recorder for his wife’s business, to pay school fees for his child and to buy wood for his carpentry business. His dream is to one day have enough money to buy modern machines for his carpentry business.

Sharifu will share the loan with his loan group, Kiponza, which totals twelve members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loans.

In the picture, Sharifu is second from left in the first row.

loans.use: To buy a recorder for his wife's business, school fees and wood for his carpentry business.

loans.name: Cristhian John

texts.es: El cliente vive en casa de sus padres en la zona de Villa Copacabana de la ciudad de La Paz, es soltero y es empleado en una imprenta, subsiste con los ingresos que obtiene. El crédito será destinado al pago de pensiones de la universidad.
texts.en:
Our client lives with his parents in the neighbourhood of Villa Copacabana in La Paz. He is unmarried and works at a printer’s. He manages to live on the wages that he earns. The loan will be used to pay for his university education.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to pay for university education

loans.name: Leonarda

texts.es:
La Sra. Leonarda S. es comerciante hace cinco años, tiene una despensa en su  domicilio en el Barrio Virgen de Fátima,  de la ciudad de Coronel Oviedo.
 Esta casada con el Sr. Pedro Vázquez hace 21 años, tienen 5 hijos juntos: Nestor 21 , Pedro 17, Fátima 10, Rosio 9, Alexis 10 meses.
Su negocio es muy importante por que es la entrada principal de la familia para el sustento de la misma, además comenta que comenzó con un pequeño kiosko y de a poco fue creciendo y a la vez le ayudo a dar el beneficio a sus hijos. Conoció el programa de la Fundación de los créditos a emprendedores y gusto mucho de la oportunidad de que la institución pudo brindarle.
 Tiene buena clientela y asegura que utilizará bien su crédito en la compra de mercaderías como bebidas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Leonarda S. has been a merchant for the last five years. She has a store in her home in Coronel Oviedo’s Virgen de Fátima neighborhood. She has been married to Mr. Pedro Vázquez for the last 21 years and they have five children: Nestor, 21, Pedro, 17, Fátima, 10, Rosio, 9, and Alexis, 10 months. Her business is very important because it’s the family’s main source of income. She comments that she started out with a small kiosk and gradually grew allowing her to benefit her children. She learned about the Fundación’s program of loans to entrepreneurs and liked the opportunity that the institution was able to offer her. She has a good customer base and assures us that she will use the loan well to buy more merchandise like beverages.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beverages like: soft drinks, wines and beers.

loans.name: Judith

texts.es: Judith, de 38 años, vive en su casa propia en compañía de su esposo Jaime de 38 años y sus 4 hijos, de los cuales 2 ya son mayores e independientes, por lo que solo se encarga de los 2 menores, y juntos habitan en un populoso barrio ubicado al norte de la ciudad. Cada día es nuevo para esta empeñosa mujer, que trabaja desde hace 2 años en su tienda de comestibles instalada en su casa. Dice que la labor en  el negocio es tranquila, pues obtiene buenas ganancias, sin descuidar su hogar, y cuando debe salir, sus hijos la apoyan y se quedan en el negocio. Asimismo manifiesta que poco a poco ha logrado implementar mejor su tienda, pues al principio empezó solo con algunos comestibles y ahora ofrece mayor variedad a sus clientes que la vistan seguido. Lo que más le gusta es interactuar con sus clientes y conversar, pues se entretiene bastante. Como es una mujer emprendedora tiene planeado surtir mejor su  tienda, además quiere también mejorar las instalaciones de su local, para dar mayor comodidad a sus compradores. Es el segundo crédito que tiene con MFP, y promete pagar sus cuotas a tiempo, porque esta muy agradecida con todas las personas que hicieron posible este aporte que le permitirá continuar trabajando en busca del progreso. Judith tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra de mercadería en comestibles, pues quiere ofrecer la mayor variedad a sus clientes, para facilitarles las compras pues el lugar donde vive es algo alejado.
texts.en:
Judith, age 38, lives in her own house with her 38 year old husband, Jaime, and their four children. Two of the children are grown and independent. Therefore, she only has the two youngest under her care. They live together in a populous neighborhood north of the city. Every day is new for this hard-working woman. For two years she has had a grocery store installed in her house. She says that the work in the business is peaceful. She gets good earnings without neglecting her household. When she needs to leave, her children help her and stay in the business. She says that, little by little, she has managed to better establish her store. At the beginning she only started with some food products, and now she offers her customers a greater variety. What she likes most about her work in interacting and talking with her customers. It is very entertaining. As an entrepreneurial woman, she plans to better stock her store. She also wants to improve her store’s facilities to make her purchasers more comfortable. This is her second loan with MFP. She pledges to make her payments on time because she is very grateful to the people who made the loan possible.
